    School means such state, county, city, church or other primary or secondary schools that teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state and shall include private schools where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. 
    Sidewalk café means an area on the sidewalk that is associated with an abutting restaurant that contains chairs and tables, and sometimes benches, that is used for the sale and the consumption of food and/or beverages, outdoors. In no circumstance shall any preparation and/or cooking of food and beverages, nor the cooling, refrigeration, storage or any other similar activity related to the preparation and serving of food and/or beverages, occur within the confines of a sidewalk café. 
    Temporary special event means an event hosted by a bona fide nonprofit civic organization in which alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises. 
    Temporary special event license means a license issued to a bona fide nonprofit civic organization, authorizing the bona fide nonprofit civic organization to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises for a period not to exceed three calendar days. 
    Wholesaler or wholesale dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages to other wholesale dealers, to retail dealers, or to retail consumption dealers. 
    Wine shall mean any alcoholic beverages containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. "Fortified wine" includes, but is not limited to, brandy. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-5. - Inspection of licensed establishments. 
    At all times that an establishment holding a license issued under this chapter is open for business, the establishment shall be open to inspection by any licensed inspector of the city, or to any person designated by the city administrator. In addition, if the premises are being used before or after hours by employees or the owners or their agents, the premises may be inspected at such time by the designated persons in this section. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-6. - License and signs to be exhibited. 
(a)  Each license issued under this chapter shall at all times be kept in public in a public area plainly exposed to view upon the licensed premises. 
(b)  All holders of a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages regulated by this chapter shall be required to post such signs in a conspicuous location in their place of business as are required by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-24.2 and Georgia Department of Revenue regulations. 
(c)  Failure to post the notices as required herein shall constitute a violation of this chapter and shall be punishable in the municipal court. The penalty contained in this section shall be in addition to any administrative penalties that may be taken with regard to the holders' license as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-7. - Responsibility of licensee for violations. 
    The licensee shall be subject to administrative penalties for any acts of their agents or their employees that are in violation of this chapter or of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-8. - Production of records; audits. 
(a)  In conjunction with any application for a license, or in conjunction with any license which has been issued under the terms hereof, or in conjunction with the revocation, suspension or cancellation of any license, or in conjunction with the payment or nonpayment of any excise tax levied or to be collected under this chapter, the city clerk or his/her designee shall have the right to demand the timely production of all or any part of the records, books, documents, electronic or magnetic media and associated software, reports or invoices of any licensee for the purpose of auditing the records of such licensee, securing compliance by such licensee with the provisions of this chapter, proving or disproving violation of any part of this chapter by any licensee, or showing payment or nonpayment of any taxes, fees, charges or the like due hereunder. 
(b)  All licensed establishments must maintain the following records for a three-year period and make the original records or certified copies available to the city upon the city's request within 72 hours: 
(1)  Monthly income or operating statements; and 
(2)  Monthly Georgia sales and use tax reports. 
(c)  Any failure to comply with the terms of this section shall subject the licensee to administrative penalties. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-9. - Invoices. 
(a)  Upon each and every delivery by a licensed wholesaler to a licensed retailer, an invoice in triplicate shall be prepared showing the quantities and brands of distilled spirits, malt beverages and wine delivered, together with the price thereof and the excise tax due and collected thereon. The original of such invoice shall be delivered by the wholesaler to the retailer simultaneously with such delivery. The wholesaler shall retain the second copy of such invoice and shall keep it for a period of 36 months after the date of delivery and during such thirty-six-month period, such invoices shall be made available for inspection by the city clerk or his/her designee or duly authorized representatives. The remaining copy of the invoice shall be distributed in accordance with Georgia law. Upon request of the city, a copy of such invoice shall be attached to any reports requested or required by the city. 
(b)  Each retailer doing business in the city shall keep and maintain accurate and complete records regarding the purchases and sales made by such business including, but not limited to, the original invoice of purchase by him from a wholesaler of any alcoholic beverages and shall maintain such records for at least 36 months after the date of such purchase. Such records shall reveal the gross sales from the operation of their business and the exact quantities of distilled spirits, malt beverages and wines by size and type of container purchased by such retail dealer together with the dates of delivery of such shipments by wholesale dealers as well as the identity of each wholesale dealer from whom such licensee purchases alcoholic beverages. The city or its duly authorized representative shall have the right to inspect the records of each retailer and make a complete audit of the records of each retailer at any time. Failure of a retailer to maintain proper records showing receipt of alcoholic beverages, payment therefore, and payment of the taxes due thereon to the appropriate wholesaler, and records which clearly show the sales, the amount of sales, and the types of sales of each retailer may, at the discretion of the city clerk or his/her designee, after a hearing as herein provided, result in the revocation or suspension of such license. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-10. - Penalties established for failure to keep records. 
(a)  If any wholesaler or retailer fails to keep and maintain the records of sales as required by this chapter or if a wholesaler or retailer refuses to allow an audit as provided by this chapter, then the license of such wholesaler or retailer shall be subject to administrative penalties. 
(b)  In the event that an audit of the records required to be kept by wholesalers and retailers under the terms of this chapter are found to vary from the monthly reports required to be furnished by the wholesalers to the city and such discrepancies are not explained to the satisfaction of the city clerk or his/her designee, the license of such wholesaler or retailer shall be subject to administrative penalties. If it appears to the city clerk or his/her designee that any retailer participated in or conspired with any wholesaler to falsify or keep and maintain incorrect records of such sales in order to avoid payment of the taxes imposed by this chapter, then all licenses of the licensees involved in such scheme shall be subject to administrative penalties as provided for under this chapter. In the event that any person intentionally falsified or intentionally failed to keep and maintain correct records of such sales, then that person shall be subject to the penalty provisions contained in the city's Charter. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-11. - Duration of licenses. 
(a)  All licenses, except as otherwise indicated, issued under this chapter shall be issued for the remaining portion of a calendar year, and all licenses shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on December 31 of each year regardless of issue date. 
(b)  No licensee shall have any vested right to renewal of any license issued hereunder. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-12. - Distance requirements. 
(a)  No person knowingly and intentionally may sell or offer to sell any distilled spirits for off-premises consumption: 
(1)  Within 200 yards of any school property; or 
(2)  Within 100 yards of any church building or alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the state or any county or municipal government therein. 
(b)  No person knowingly and intentionally may sell or offer to sell for off-premises consumption any malt beverages or wines: 
(1)  Within 100 yards of any school property; or 
(2)  Within 100 yards of any alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the state or any county or municipal government therein. 
(c)  No person knowingly and intentionally may sell or offer to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  Within 100 yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the state or any county or municipal government therein. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-13. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Retail distilled spirits. The exterior entrances of retail stores for the sale of distilled spirits hereunder must be locked during the hours for which the sale of any distilled spirits is prohibited. Licensees shall not engage in the sale of any distilled spirits except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. 
(b)  Retail malt beverages and wines. Licensees in the retail sale of malt beverages and wines shall be allowed to engage in the sale of such beverages for 24 hours a day Monday through Saturday and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. until 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. 
(c)  Consumption on the premises. No distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine shall be sold for consumption on the premises except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 a.m. of the following morning on Monday through Friday, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and 1:00 a.m. of the following Sunday morning, and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sunday. Each and every person shall be required to vacate the premises no later than one hour past any required closing time. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-14. - Exterior advertisement prohibited. 
(a)  No placard or sign which is visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall make reference to the price of any distilled spirits sold therein, except that tags showing the prices of individual bottles or containers may be affixed to the bottles or containers or to the edge of the shelf whereon the bottles or containers are located. 
(b)  Advertisement of malt beverages or wines cannot be affixed or displayed in the window of any establishment licensed for retail sale. Any placards or advertisements of malt beverages or wines must be displayed from inside the location. There shall be no advertisements to the price of any malt beverages or wines visible from the outside of such establishment. 
(c)  No show-window advertising or display shall be visible from the exterior of the primary use structure, and no sign shall be erected anywhere within the city advertising the sale of distilled spirits by the drink. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-15. - Prohibition on service of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to serve, dispense, or sell an alcoholic beverage while under the influence of alcohol. 
(b)  If an employee violates this section, then the licensee shall be subject to administrative penalties. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-16. - Payment of taxes and fees. 
    Prior to issuance of any license pursuant to this chapter, an applicant must be in compliance with all applicable requirements under federal, state, and/or city ordinances. Compliance with state and city statute and ordinances shall specifically include the requirement that the applicant or business of the applicant is not delinquent in the payment of any tax or fee owed the city, including, but not limited to, personal or real property taxes, any occupational taxes, sales and use taxes, or payment for any required permit necessary for operation of applicant's business. For purposes of this section, any tax that has been paid, formally appealed to the proper authorities, or is being paid pursuant to a plan authorized and approved by the appropriate tax or revenue commissioner shall not be deemed delinquent. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-17-6-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 6-20. - Application procedures. 
    All persons must follow the applicable procedures hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-21. - Procedure for considering application. 
    The city clerk or his/her designee shall not consider any application for a license until the written application provided for herein is made, the investigative fee paid, the plat required herein filed and the fingerprinting and investigation of all persons as required under this chapter has been completed by the sheriff's department. The sheriff's department shall, upon completion of the investigation, file a written report of the results of such investigation, which report shall be attached to said application and form a part of the permanent city record. Upon the completion of all of the foregoing, the application, together with all data, shall be submitted to the city clerk or his/her designee for consideration pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-22. - Application; data; information; requirement for. 
    Applicants are required to complete all aspects of all prescribed forms required under this chapter. The failure to provide all information required by such forms may result in denial of any application under this chapter. All applicants shall furnish all omitted data, information and records requested of them by the city clerk or his/her designee, and the failure to furnish such omitted data, information and records within 30 calendar days from the date of such request shall automatically serve to cause such application to be denied. The applicants, by filing an application for a license permitted under this chapter, agree to produce, for oral interview, any person or persons requested by the city clerk or his/her designee , considered by either as being important in ascertaining the facts relative to such application and/or licenses issued under this chapter. The failure to produce such person or persons within 30 calendar days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic denial of any application pending under this chapter. The application form and all data requested by the city clerk or his/her designee shall be subscribed by the applicant(s) under oath before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. Any untrue or misleading information contained in, or material statement omitted from, an original, renewal or transfer application for a license shall be cause for the denial or revocation thereof. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-23. - Citizenship; residence requirements; corporation requirements. 
    No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be issued in the name of any individual who is not a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully permitted for permanent residence. Where the applicant is a corporation or other business entity other than an individual, any person, stockholder or principal owning more than a ten percent financial interest must meet the requirements contained herein as if the license was to be issued in their name, and in the event any license provided for hereunder shall be issued, such license shall be issued in the name of the corporation or business entity and the principal stockholder or principal behind such business entity. If the applicant is a partnership, the requirements contained herein shall be met by all partners, whether general or limited partners. If the applicant in whose name a license under this chapter is issued is not a county resident, such person must appoint and continuously maintain in the county a designated agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required under this chapter may be served. The registered agent must be a resident of the county. If the licensee is not a natural person, such as a corporation, it will be required to appoint and maintain a designated agent in the county if it does not have in the county any agent upon whom process can legally be served for such entity under the laws of the state. The license[e] shall file the name of such registered agent, along with the written consent to serve of such agent, with the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-24. - Annexation of licensed businesses. 
    Any person, persons, establishment or other entity that holds a license from a county for the sale of alcoholic beverages and that is located in an area annexed by the city, shall have 30 calendar days from the effective date of the annexation to apply for the appropriate licenses and permits under this chapter. However, all applicable fees and costs for the equivalent license(s) in the city shall be waived for the year of annexation. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-25. - Other licenses. 
    The license fees provided for in this chapter are not levied in lieu of any other license fees or taxes that may be levied upon licensees, but are in addition thereto. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-26. - Applications for license. 
(a)  The provisions of this Code regarding occupation taxes shall apply in addition to the provisions in this section. 
(b)  All applications for licenses under this chapter shall be accompanied by a payment in cash, credit/debit card, personal/business check, or by cashiers/certified check, for all the fees and occupation taxes provided for in the city's Code for the classification into which the applicant falls. 
(c)  All city applications shall be in original form and shall be accompanied by a full photocopy of all the appropriate state applications. 
(d)  Any false statement or material misrepresentation in any application hereunder shall be grounds for the denial of any application or for the revocation of any license granted hereunder. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-27. - Notice of intention to secure license for sale of distilled spirits. 
(a)  No application for a license for the sale of distilled spirits, either for retail sale or for consumption on premises, shall be acted upon until after the applicant has published in the newspaper that publishes the legal advertisements of the city a notice of his intention to secure a license for sale of distilled spirits. Such notice shall be published three times during the 30 calendar days immediately preceding the filing of the application for a license. Such notice shall be in large boldface type and shall state: 
(1)  The type of license for which application has been filed; 
(2)  The exact location of the place of business for which a license is sought; 
(3)  The names and addresses of each owner of the business; and 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, the names and titles of all corporate officers. 
(b)  Proof of publication of the notice required by this section shall be attached to an application for a license for sale of distilled spirits, both for retail sale and for consumption on premises. 
(c)  An applicant for a renewal license for the sale of distilled spirits shall not be subject to the notice requirements of this section. However, the notice section shall apply to all other applications for a license for the sale of distilled spirits, including, but not limited to, an application involving a new business, a change of location and a change of license holder. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-28. - Application forms. 
(a)  All persons desiring to receive a license shall make application on a form prescribed by the city clerk or his/her designee. No application will be processed until the applicant has completed the required interview with the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(b)  The application shall include but shall not be limited to: the name and address of the applicant; the proposed business to be carried on; if a partnership, the names and residence address of the partners, the name of the manager, and the name of all shareholders holding more than ten percent of any class of corporate stock, or any other entity having a financial interest in each entity which is to own or operate the establishment for which a license is sought. If the manager changes, the applicant must furnish the city clerk or his/her designee the name and address of the new manager and other information as requested within ten calendar days of such change. 
(c)  There shall be separate processing fees to cover the expense of an investigation and the expense of processing the application, which fees shall not be refundable. The amount of the investigation fee and the processing fee for the application shall be as established by the city council, from time to time. 
(d)  All applications shall contain proof that the location of the proposed premises complies with all zoning and planning requirements. 
(e)  All applicants shall furnish data, information and records as required by the city clerk or his/her designee and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the application to be denied. 
(f)  A complete set of fingerprints of each applicant for a new license shall be required. 
(1)  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a) (1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled "Dissemination of information to public agencies, political subdivisions, authorities, and instrumentalities." 
(2)  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive an alcoholic beverage license shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for a new license. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the city obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). While fingerprinting shall typically only be required at the time of the initial application, the submission by the applicant of a renewal application shall authorize the city to request a new set of fingerprints if needed and shall authorize the city to once again obtain the applicant's criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
(3)  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
a.  The city is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a) (1.2). 
b.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all Georgia laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
c.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
d.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
(4)  Administration; fees; procedures. 
a.  Applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints, which may be taken by the county sheriff's department or may be taken at any Georgia applicant processing services location so long as the applicant registers in such a manner that allows the county sheriff's department to receive the criminal history results. 
b.  The applicant shall bear the cost of the electronic fingerprinting submission services set by the Georgia Applicant Processing Services and an administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the city, which shall be the maximum allowed by statute, which is currently $20.00, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the county sheriff's department. 
c.  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the city will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the city police department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the FBI for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the FBI is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the FBI check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the city Police Department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the GBI and FBI where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
d.  In compliance with Federal law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a "fitness determination," the city will decide whether the applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
e.  A person who has consented to the city for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the city at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to Georgia records and/or the FBI concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(g)  All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(h)  The city shall have 60 calendar days to process any completed application for a license under the terms of this chapter, provided that the 60 calendar days may be extended by agreement of the applicant and the city. In the event that the city does not issue a decision on the completed application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present application only. 
(i)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied under the provisions of this chapter, which shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. 
(j)  In the event the applicant is denied a license by the state, any alcoholic beverage license fee paid to the city shall be refunded, but all other application and investigative fees paid to the city shall be retained by the city. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-29. - Separate application and separate license for each location of sale. 
    A separate application must be made for each location of sale, and, if such application is granted, a separate license must be issued for each location of sale. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-30. - Restriction upon transfers. 
    Licenses under this chapter may not be transferred to another person except as otherwise provided in this chapter. Instead, all persons desiring licenses shall make application to the city for a new license and pay any appropriate fees and occupation taxes, and that person must otherwise meet the requirements hereunder for a new license. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-31. - Change of location. 
(a)  All persons desiring to change the physical location of their premises where alcoholic beverages are sold shall make application on a form prescribed by the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(b)  An application for a change of location shall include the following information: 
(1)  Proof of planning and zoning compliance; 
(2)  Proof of building code compliance; 
(3)  A legal description of the property upon which the new premises is located; and 
(4)  An affidavit from a registered surveyor stating that the establishment complies with any distance or location requirements contained in this chapter or otherwise imposed by law or regulation. 
(c)  There shall be separate processing fees to cover the expense of an investigation and the expense of processing the change of location application, which fees shall not be refundable. The amount of the investigation fee and the processing fee for the application shall be as established by the city council, from time to time. 
(d)  Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the change of location application to be denied. 
(e)  The city shall have 60 calendar days to process any completed change of location application, provided that the 60 calendar days may be extended by agreement of the applicant and the city. In the event that the city does not issue a decision on the completed change of location application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present change of location application only. 
(f)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied under the provisions of this chapter, which shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  If the proposed change of location relates to a license for the sale of distilled spirits on the premises or off-premises, the change of location application shall not be acted upon until the applicant has published in the newspaper which publishes the legal advertisements of the city a notice of his intention to change locations for the sale of distilled spirits. Such notice shall be published at least once during the 30 calendar days immediately preceding request for a change of location. Such notice shall be in large boldface type and shall state: 
(1)  The exact location of the place of business for which the change is being sought; 
(2)  The names and addresses of each owner of the business; and 
(3)  If the applicant is a corporation, the names and titles of all corporate officers. 
(h)  Proof of publication of the notice required by this section shall be attached to an application for change of location. 
(i)  Any change of location allowed under this section may be denied or revoked on the same basis as for an application for license under this chapter. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-32. - Effect of expiration, surrender, revocation or suspension of license. 
    In the event that a license expires, is surrendered, revoked or suspended, the establishment shall immediately cease selling alcoholic beverages as of 11:59 p.m. on the date of said expiration, surrender, revocation or suspension. Any appeal procedures related to the suspension or revocation of a license by the city that is utilized by a licensee, as set forth herein, shall have the effect of tolling any revocation or suspension of the license until the appeal process has become final. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-33. - Substitution of licensee. 
(a)  In the event that a licensee severs his association with a licensed establishment, whether by resignation or by termination with his employer, then the establishment may continue to sell alcoholic beverages under the existing license for a period not to exceed 45 calendar days from the date that is determined to be the date of severance which shall be subject to being shortened in the event that the license expires or is suspended or revoked. 
(b)  The application for a substitute licensee shall require substantially the same information as the initial application, including a complete investigation of the criminal history of the licensee. 
(c)  There shall be separate processing fees to cover the expense of an investigation and the expense of processing the substitute licensee application, which fees shall not be refundable. The amount of the investigation fee and the processing fee for the application shall be as established by the city council, from time to time. 
(d)  Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the substitute licensee application to be denied. 
(e)  The city shall have 60 calendar days to process any completed substitute licensee application, provided that the 60 calendar days may be extended by agreement of the applicant and the city. In the event that the city does not issue a decision on the completed substitute licensee application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present substitute licensee application only. 
(f)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied, which shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. This section shall not prohibit transfer of stock between persons who held stock in the corporate ownership at the time of issuance of the license. 
(h)  A licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders; provided, however, that any additional partners or any new stockholders holding more than ten percent of any class of corporate stock must be approved by the city council as provided hereunder. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-34. - License required. 
(a)  No malt beverage, wines, distilled spirits or any other alcoholic beverage shall be sold or manufactured in the city except under a license issued under this chapter by the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(b)  The requirements of this chapter shall be in addition to any other requirements for occupation taxes under this Code and if other provisions of the Code conflict with this chapter, then this chapter shall control. 
(c)  Licenses which may be issued under this chapter include: 
(1)  Manufacturing alcoholic beverages; 
(2)  Wholesale malt beverages and wines; 
(3)  Wholesale distilled spirits; 
(4)  Retail malt beverages and wines; 
(5)  Retail distilled spirits; 
(6)  Consumption on the premises malt beverages and wines; 
(7)  Consumption on the premises distilled spirits; 
(8)  Sales off-premises for catered functions; 
(9)  Any combination of subsection (c)(2) and (3) of this section; 
(10)  Any combination under subsection (c)(4) and (5) of this section; 
(11)  Any combination under subsection (c)(6) and (7) of this section; 
(12)  Bottle house; and 
(13)  Brew pub. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-35. - Annual renewal. 
(a)  Licensees shall make a written application for renewal of licenses issued under this chapter on forms supplied by the city clerk or his/her designee by November 15 of each year, which application may require substantially the same information as the initial application, including a complete investigation of the criminal history of the licensee. 
(b)  If the city clerk or his/her designee determines that it would be appropriate under the standards set forth within this chapter to renew the license under consideration, then he/she shall be authorized to approve the application for renewal. Any license which has not been renewed and paid for in full by close of business on the last business day prior to the end of the calendar year shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on December 31 and shall not serve to authorize the license holder to perform under such license after that date and time until such time as the new license has been issued to the license holder. 
(c)  Any license which is not renewed during the calendar year during which it was issued but is renewed by January 31 of the subsequent year shall be charged an administrative surcharge of ten percent of the license fee in addition to the license fee itself. 
(d)  Any license which is not renewed during the calendar year during which it was issued and is not renewed by January 31 of the subsequent year shall not be renewed. Any person desiring to have a license issued for such an establishment shall be required to initiate a new application process. 
(e)  The city shall have a minimum of 30 calendar days to review a completed license renewal application. In the event that the city does not issue a decision on the completed renewal application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present renewal application only. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-36. - Amount of fees to be set by city council. 
    All fees associated with alcohol licensing shall be determined from time to time and set by the city council. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-37. - Annual fees. 
    All annual license fees herein shall be paid prior to the issuance of the license. Any new license granted hereunder during a calendar year shall pay the full license fee without proration; provided, however, that if a license is granted after July 1, the license fee shall be one-half of the annual licenses for the remainder of such calendar year. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-38. - Miscellaneous. 
    In case of death of any person holding a license, or any interest therein, the license may, with the approval by motion of the city council, and subject to the terms of this chapter, be transferred to the administrator, executor or personal representative of the deceased person, or to the heirs at law of the deceased person, if such heirs meet all of the other qualifications contained herein. The license of the deceased person shall be held by the administrator, executor or personal representative of the deceased person only for the time necessary to complete administration of his estate and to dispose of the license or the interest therein, but in no event shall exceed 12 months. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-39-6-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSIDERATION OF LICENSE APPLICATIONS 

Sec. 6-50. - Considerations for granting a license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall have the discretion to grant or refuse to grant any application for a license hereunder; however, the city clerk or his/her designee shall consider the following matters in connection with each application for a license hereunder, which considerations are deemed to be in the public interest and welfare, as follows: 
(1)  Whether the applicant, or any person having a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the issuance of the license, has had any license issued by the city or by any other city in the state, or by any other licensing authority in the state relating to the manufacture, distribution or sale of alcoholic beverages suspended within the past five years or revoked within the past ten years; 
(2)  Whether any applicant for a license to sell distilled spirits or package beer and wine, or any person having a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the issuance of the license, has had any license issued by the city or by any other city in the state, or by any other licensing authority in the state relating to the manufacture, distribution or sale of alcoholic beverages suspended within the past five years or revoked within the past ten years; 
(3)  Whether the applicant or any person owning a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license for which application is made has sufficient mental capacity to conduct the business for which the application is made; 
(4)  Whether the applicant or any person owning a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license for which application is made has been dishonorably discharged from the armed services of the United States; 
(5)  Whether the applicant or any person owning a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license for which application is made fails to demonstrate financial stability; 
(6)  Whether the applicant is 21 years of age or older; 
(7)  Whether the applicant is a citizen of the United States or a resident alien lawfully permitted for permanent residence; 
(8)  Whether the location of the premises from which the proposed sale of alcoholic beverages shall be conducted meets the distance restrictions set forth by state law and local ordinance; 
(9)  Whether the applicant, owner, and manager have obtained a valid alcoholic beverage handling permit as required by this chapter; 
(10)  The applicant's reputation, character, criminal history, and mental and physical capacity to conduct the business proposed to be conducted; 
(11)  Whether the applicant has been convicted of, pled guilty to, or entered a plea of nolo contendere to, or is presently charged with any felony, any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, any criminal offense related to lottery rules or regulations, any offense related to illegal gambling, soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting of premises for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, any offense related to the illegal possession or sale of illegal drugs or alcoholic beverages, any sex offense found in O.C.G.A. Title 16, Chapter 6 or any similar violation found in any other state or federal statute, any charges related to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, or a second offense of driving under the influence of alcohol within the last ten years; 
(12)  Whether the applicant, or any person who shall have a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license, as a previous holder of a license to sell any type of alcoholic beverages has been found to have violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business within a ten-year period, immediately preceding the date of the application for license hereunder; 
(13)  If applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell any type of alcoholic beverages, the manner in which he or she conducted the business under such license and the necessity for any unusual police observation and inspection of such prior business in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business; 
(14)  If applicant has had a prior license, whether any such prior license for the sale of any type of alcoholic beverages has been suspended or revoked or whether or not hearings have been held for the revocation or suspension of any such license regardless of whether or not any such license was revoked or suspended as a result of such hearing; 
(16)  Whether the applicant, or any person who shall have a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license, has had any city license revoked within two years prior to the filing of the application; 
(17)  Whether the facility where the applicant proposes to sell alcoholic beverages meets city zoning requirements; 
(18)  Whether it appears that the applicant would have adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or whether it appears that the applicant is intended to be a mere surrogate for a person or persons who would not otherwise qualify for a license for any reason whatsoever; and 
(19)  Whether the applicant has failed to meet any other criteria specified by this chapter or state law. 
(b)  The city clerk or his/her designee has discretionary authority to consider any other objective criteria that is rationally related to the application including any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application, or the proposed location of the business when making a decision to approve or deny a license requested hereunder. If, in the judgment of the city clerk or his/her designee, circumstances are such that granting the license would not be in the best interest of the general health, safety, and public welfare, such circumstances shall be grounds for denying the application. 
(c)  The city clerk or his/her designee may issue any city license provided for in this chapter only after a motion to that effect is adopted by the city council. The city clerk or his/her designee may issue a license for the off-premises sale of alcoholic beverages for catered functions without the necessity of city council approval. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-51. - Continuing duty to report criminal convictions. 
    All license holders shall have a continuing duty to notify the city in writing in the event that the license holder or any shareholder or partner that holds a ten percent or greater interest in the entity to whom the license is issued is charged with, is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendre to any criminal offense under the laws of this state or any other state or other jurisdiction after a license has been granted. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-52. - Payment of taxes and other debts to the city. 
    The city clerk or his/her designee shall cause an inquiry to be made into the tax records of the city to determine if any applicant or any shareholder or partner that holds a ten percent or greater interest in the entity to whom the license is issued have any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent or any other monies owing to the city. No license shall be issued, nor shall a license be renewed, until all such debts are paid in full. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-53. - Change in relationships and/or ownership interest. 
    Any change in any of the ownership interest contained on the original application for a license or for an application for the renewal of an existing license must be filed in writing with the city clerk or his/her designee within 30 calendar days after such change is made. The failure to do so shall be grounds for the imposition of administrative penalties or for the immediate denial of any pending application for such a license or for the renewal of such a license. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-54. - Completion of proposed licensed premises. 
    Where a building in which an applicant proposes to operate under a license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages is at the time of the application for such license not in existence, or not yet completed, a license may be issued for such location providing the plans and specifications for the proposed building are filed with the city clerk or his/her designee and show clear compliance with the other provisions of this chapter and other applicable ordinances of the city. No sales shall be allowed in such location until the location has been completed in accordance with said plans and specifications and is in conformity with all other provisions of this chapter, all building codes, and other applicable ordinances of the city and until a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-55. - Application for new license in existing license location. 
    An application for a new license in an existing license location shall be required to comply with all requirements of this chapter for the granting of a new license except that an application for an annual renewal license shall not be subject to the notice requirements of section 6-27. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-56-6-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCISE TAXES 

Sec. 6-60. - Retail sales of distilled spirits by the drink. 
    Every purchaser at retail of distilled spirits by the drink in the city shall pay a tax thereon at the rate of three percent of such retail price or charge for such drink, or at such higher rate as may be permitted by the laws of [the] state. Such tax shall be collected by the retail consumption dealer, who shall remit such tax to the city clerk or his or her designee on or before the 15 th day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the retail consumption dealer's gross sales derived from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk or his or her designee. Credit card sales shall be reported as part of gross sales, and taxes collected on such credit card sales shall be submitted to the city in the same manner as required for cash sales. Each retail consumption dealer shall be allowed a deduction equal to the rate authorized for deductions from state tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50, as amended from time to time, provided that such tax is not delinquent at the time of payment. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-61. - Sales of distilled spirits and wine. 
    There is levied an excise tax computed at the rate of $0.22 per liter, including a proportionate amount calculated at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter, on all sales of distilled spirits and wine in the city by wholesalers to retail consumption dealers and retail package dealers. Such tax shall be paid to the city clerk by the wholesaler selling such distilled spirits or wine to any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer on or before the 15 th day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the wholesaler's gross sales of distilled spirits and wine in the county during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the director. Wine containing less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any wholesaler to sell, ship or deliver, in any manner, any distilled spirits or wine to a retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer without collecting such tax. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display or sell any distilled spirits or wine on which such tax has not been paid. Each wholesaler shall be paid three percent of the amount of taxes collected as reimbursement for collection of the tax, provided that the tax is paid on or before its due date. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-62. - Sales of malt beverages. 
    There is levied an excise tax on all malt beverages sold by wholesalers to retail consumption dealers and retail package dealers and brewers in the city at the highest rate allowed by the state, but not less than the following: 
(1)  Where malt beverages are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 151/2 gallons, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 151/2 gallons; and 
(2)  Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces, and a proportionate rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. Malt beverages which contain less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax. Such tax shall be paid to the city clerk or his/her designee by the wholesaler selling the malt beverages to any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer on or before the 15 th day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the wholesaler's gross sales of malt beverages in the city during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk or his or her designee. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-63. - Deficiency determination. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk or his or her designee is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax to be paid to the city by any person, the city clerk or his or her designee may cause an audit of the books and records of the licensee to be performed and may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within the city clerk or his or her designee's possession or that may come into the city clerk or his or her designee's possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. It shall be the duty of each licensee subject to the collection or payment of any of the excise taxes set forth in this chapter to keep and preserve his or her records relative to the collection and payment of such taxes for three years. 
(b)  Interest. The amount of the deficiency determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 15 th day after the close of the monthly period in which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment thereof. 
(c)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a deficiency determination, the city clerk or his or her designee may offset overpayments for a period against underpayments for another period, penalties and the interest on underpayments. 
(d)  Penalty for negligence or disregard of rules and regulations. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty of 15 percent of the amount of such deficiency shall be added to the tax. 
(e)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination is made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any provision of section 6-60, 6-61, or 6-62, or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the deficiency shall be added to such tax. 
(f)  Notice of clerk's determination; service of. The city clerk or his or her designee shall give to the licensee written notice of a deficiency determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If such service is made by mail, such service shall be made pursuant to section 6-37. 
(g)  Time within which notice is to be mailed. Except in the case of fraud, intent to evade the provisions of this chapter or authorized rules and regulations, or failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 15 th day of every month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-64. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return, the city clerk or his or her designee shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee or of the total sales in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is in or may come into the possession of the city clerk or his or her designee. Upon the basis of such estimate, the city clerk or his or her designee shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city, adding to such determined sum a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or more periods. 
(b)  Offsetting of overpayments. If making a determination, the city clerk or his or her designee may offset overpayments for a period or penalties against the interest on the underpayments. 
(c)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 15 th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount, or any portion thereof, should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(d)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If the failure of any person to file a return is due to fraud or an intent to evade section 6-60, 6-61, or 6-62 or rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the amount required to be paid by the person, exclusive of penalties, shall be added thereto in addition to the 15 percent penalty provided in section 6-63(d). 
(e)  Giving of notice; manner of service. Promptly after making his or her determination, the city clerk or his or her designee shall give to the person written notice, to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice in section 6-37. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-65. - Collection. 
(a)  Security. Whenever the city clerk or his or her designee deems it necessary to ensure compliance with section 6-60, 6-61, or 6-62 he/she may require any person subject to such sections to deposit with him or her such security as the city clerk or his or her designee may determine. The amount of the security shall be fixed by the city clerk or his or her designee, but shall not be greater than twice the person's estimated average liability for the period for which he or she files returns, determined in such a manner as the city clerk or his or her designee deems proper, or $10,000.00, whichever amount is the lesser. The amount of the security may be increased by the city clerk or his or her designee subject to the limitations provided in this section. The city clerk or his or her designee may sell the security at public auction, with the approval of the council, if it becomes necessary to do so in order to recover any tax or any amount required to be collected, interest or penalty due. Notice of the sale may be served upon the person who deposited the security personally or by mail. If service is by mail, it shall be made in the manner prescribed for service of a notice of determined deficiency and shall be addressed to the person at his or her address as it appears in the records of the city clerk or his or her designee. Upon any sale, any surplus above the amounts due shall be returned to the person who deposited the security. 
(b)  Notice of delinquency to persons holding credits or property of delinquent; duty of persons so notified. If any person is delinquent in the payment of the amount required to be paid by him or her, or if a delinquency determination has been made against him or her which remains unpaid, the city clerk or his or her designee may, not later than three years after the payment became delinquent, give notice thereof by registered mail to all persons in the city having in their possession or under their control any credits or other personal property belonging to the delinquent, or owing any debts to the delinquent. After receiving the notice, the persons so notified shall neither transfer nor make any other disposition of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession or under their control at the time they receive the notice until the city clerk or his or her designee consents to a transfer or disposition, or until 20 days elapse after the receipt of the notice. All persons so notified shall, within five days after receipt of the notice, advise the city clerk or his or her designee of all of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession, under their control or owing by them. 
(c)  Action for tax collection. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this chapter becomes due and payable, and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this chapter, the city clerk or his or her designee may bring an action in the courts of this state, any other state or of the United States in the name of city to collect the amount delinquent, together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(d)  Duty of successors or assignees of licensee to withhold tax from purchase money. If any licensee liable for any amount under section 6-60, 6-61, or 6-62 sells out his or her business or quits the business, his or her successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city clerk or his or her designee showing that he or she has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(e)  Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase price as required, he or she becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him or her to the extent of the purchase price valued in money. Within 30 days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the city clerk or his or her designee shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his or her address, as it appears on the records of the city clerk or his or her designee, of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of the successor may be enforced shall begin at the time the licensee sells out his or her business or at the time that the determination against the licensee becomes final, whichever occurs later. 
(f)  Refund of tax, penalty or interest paid more than once or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under section 6-60, 6-61, or 6-62, it may be offset as provided in section 6-63(c) or it may be refunded provided a verified claim in writing therefor, stating the specific grounds upon which the claim is founded, is filed with the city clerk or his or her designee within three years from the date of payment. The claim shall be audited and shall be made on forms provided by the city clerk or his or her designee. If the claim is approved by the city clerk or his or her designee and the council, the excess amount collected or paid may be refunded or may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person from whom it was collected or by whom paid, and the balance may be refunded to such person, his or her administrators or executors. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-66-6-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONSUMPTION ON PREMISES; LICENSING REQUIREMENTS, REGULATION AND TYPES OF LICENSES 

Sec. 6-70. - License permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises for consumption on the premises. 
(a)  Only the following types of establishments or activities shall be licensed under this article for the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  Restaurants; 
(2)  Brewpubs; 
(3)  Drinking places; 
(4)  Hotel/lounge; 
(5)  Nightclub; 
(6)  Indoor commercial recreational establishments; 
(7)  Golf course; and 
(8)  Performing arts facility. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-71. - Issuance of licenses limited to designated business; occupational tax certificate. 
(a)  No license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall be issued to any person unless the business or the proposed business to be licensed hereunder is a restaurant, brewpub, drinking place, hotel/lounge, nightclub, indoor commercial recreational establishment, golf course, or performing arts facility as each of these terms is defined in this chapter. 
(b)  Licenses shall only be issued for a business that is a permitted use in that particular zoning district and no license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises may be issued to any business licensed for operating as any type of adult entertainment establishment. 
(c)  No license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall be issued to any person unless the business or the proposed business to be licensed hereunder has made application for and received an occupation tax certificate as a restaurant, performing arts facility, hotel, lounge, drinking place, nightclub, indoor commercial recreational establishment, golf course or brewpub. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-72. - Off-premises sale of alcoholic beverages for catered functions. 
(a)  In addition to the occupation tax requirements of this Code and article I of this chapter, the following requirements shall apply to the licensing and operations for sales of alcoholic beverages off-premises for catered functions. Should this section conflict with any other provisions of this chapter or the occupation tax requirements of this Code, then this section shall control. 
(b)  Any applicant who holds a license by the city under the terms and conditions set forth in chapter 6 to sell malt beverages or wine by the drink for consumption on the premises may be issued an off-premises license that authorizes such applicant to sell malt beverages or wine by the drink off-premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. Any applicant not licensed by the city who possesses a valid license from a jurisdiction within the State of Georgia to sell malt beverages or wine by the drink for consumption on the premises may be issued a license that authorizes such applicant to sell malt beverages or wine by the drink at an authorized catered function upon presentation of a copy of such license from the applicant's original issuing jurisdiction. For the purposes of this section, the term "authorized catered function" may include a function held inside a publicly or privately owned building or structure or a function held outside such a building or structure that is located within the city limits of the city. 
(c)  Any applicant who holds a license issued by the city under the terms and conditions set forth in chapter 6 which authorizes the applicant to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises may be issued an off-premises license which authorizes such applicant to sell distilled spirits by the drink off-premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. For purposes of this section the term "authorized catered function" may include a function held inside a publicly or privately owned building or structure or a function held outside such a building or structure that is located within the city limits of the city. 
(d)  In order to distribute or sell distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine at an authorized catered function, an applicant shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply to the city for an alcoholic beverage catered event permit. The application shall include the name of the applicant; the date, address and time of the event; and the applicant's alcoholic beverage license number. 
(2)  If applicable, provide satisfactory reports as required to the state on forms provided by the state, stating the quantity of any and all alcoholic beverages transported from the applicant's primary premises to the location of the authorized catered function and such other information as may be required by the state. 
(3)  If applicable, maintain original event permits and documents in the vehicle transporting the alcoholic beverage to the catered function at all times. 
(4)  Pay an alcoholic beverage catered event permit fee according to the schedule approved from time to time by the city council. 
(e)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall review the applicant's application and supporting documentation. Based upon the requirements set forth in this section, the city clerk or his/her designee shall either approve or deny, in writing, said alcoholic beverage catered event application. 
(f)  All alcoholic beverage catered event applications must be submitted at least 20 calendar days prior to the planned event. 
(g)  No limitations will be applied as to the number of alcoholic beverage catered event license applications made by a retail consumption dealer in any one calendar year. 
(h)  The restrictions set forth in the section 6-13, hours of operation, shall apply to all sales of alcoholic beverages at authorized catered functions. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017; Res. of 3-12-2018) 
Sec. 6-73. - Restaurants. 
(a)  An establishment may be licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises as a restaurant where the establishment meets all other applicable requirements under this chapter. 
(b)  A restaurant licensee shall be allowed to serve alcoholic beverages to persons seated at that restaurant's sidewalk café, if a sidewalk café permit has been issued to the restaurant. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-74. - Bottle house. 
(a)  A bottle house license is not a license for selling alcoholic beverages of any type. 
(b)  A bottle house license allows specific places of business to allow patrons to bring in and consume their own alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(c)  Businesses that are eligible for licensure as a bottle house must have a primary business that fits the Code of Ordinances definition for: bed and breakfast, art shop, nail salon, or spa. 
(d)  The individual that supplies the alcoholic beverage must remove any unconsumed beverage from the facility. 
(e)  The brown bagging of alcoholic beverages will be subject to this chapter and to state law; including but not limited to prohibition of consumption by one who is under 21 years of age, or intoxicated. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any licensed bottle house to store any alcoholic beverage on the premises, except for temporary storage in a refrigerator or cooler while the person who furnished the alcoholic beverage is still in the place of business. 
(g)  In the case of a bed and breakfast the resident owner/manager can store alcoholic beverages for his/her own personal consumption. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-75. - Brewpub licenses. 
(a)  No person shall be permitted to own or operate a brewpub without first obtaining consumption on premises license from the city clerk or his/her designee, and each brewpub license holder shall comply with all other applicable state and local license requirements. 
(b)  Possession of a brewpub license shall not prevent the holder of such license from obtaining another license authorized under section 6-70 (license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises) for the same premises. 
(c)  A brewpub license does not authorize the holder of such license to sell alcoholic beverages at retail by package for consumption off the premises. 
(d)  A brewpub licensee shall pay all state and local license fees and excise taxes applicable to individuals licensed as manufacturers, retailers, and, where applicable, wholesalers. 
(e)  A brewpub licensee shall measure all beer manufactured on the premises and otherwise comply with applicable regulations respecting excise and enforcement tax determination of such beer as required. There is hereby levied an excise tax on all beer and malt beverage produced by a brewpub in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80, as amended. Such tax shall be paid to city hall no later than the tenth day of each month for the preceding month's production. A late payment penalty not to exceed ten percent of the tax otherwise due shall be added to the amount due for any payment not received by the due date. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-76. - Performing arts facility. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages may be sold and/or dispensed at a performing arts facility only where the facility meets the definition for a performing arts facility set forth herein. 
(b)  A business meeting the definition of a performing arts facility under this chapter shall be eligible to apply for and be considered for an annual license to allow alcoholic beverages to be sold for consumption on the premises from the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(c)  A business granted a performing arts facility license for consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises shall be required to obtain all required licenses from the state and to follow all state and local laws, ordinances and rules governing the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(d)  Alcoholic beverages may be sold at a performing arts facility only at a bar located in the lobby area of the facility or by a waiter or waitress serving patrons within the facility. 
(e)  In addition to the hours of sale requirements set out in this chapter, alcoholic beverages may not be dispensed at a performing arts facility earlier than one hour before the start of a performance or later than one hour after the performance has ended, provided that no alcoholic beverages shall be sold past the hours listed in this chapter for retail consumption on premise licensees. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-77. - Indoor commercial recreation establishments. 
    Indoor commercial recreation establishments that are licensed to serve alcoholic beverages shall only sell alcoholic beverages at a bar or by a waiter or waitress in the dining or bar areas at tables located therein. Alcoholic beverages shall not be sold in the areas of the establishment not intended predominately for food or beverage consumption. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-78. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-79. - Pitchers. 
(a)  No consumption on the premises licensee shall sell, offer to sell or deliver alcoholic beverages, including malt beverages, in any container that holds more than 32 fluid ounces at any one time to one person. 
(b)  A consumption on the premises licensee may sell, offer to sell or deliver alcoholic beverages, including malt beverages, in a pitcher containing not more than 64 fluid ounces to a group of persons consisting of at least two or more persons. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-80. - Courtyard, patio, and deck sales. 
(a)  For the purposes of this chapter, an establishment may include a courtyard, patio, and/or deck area as a part of their premises within which they are allowed to serve and sell alcoholic beverages if: 
(1)  The courtyard, patio, or deck is separated from the general public by a permanent wall, fence, hedge, or similar device or structure that is approved by the building official or his/her designee; 
(2)  The patrons of the establishment may only access the courtyard, patio, or deck area through the primary structure of the establishment; 
(3)  The location of the courtyard, patio, or deck does not encroach upon any public sidewalk, any public right-of-way, or any other area customarily used for ingress to the primary structure of the establishment, egress from the primary structure of the establishment, pedestrian traffic, or vehicular traffic; 
(4)  The location and placement of the courtyard, patio, or deck shall first have been approved by the city clerk or his/her designee; and 
(5)  The plans for the courtyard, patio, or deck shall first have been approved by the building official or his/her designee as being in conformity with applicable city building codes and all other applicable codes. 
(b)  The use of the courtyard, patio, or deck shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The use of the courtyard, patio, or deck shall be subject to the city's noise and nuisance ordinances and shall be subject to applicable state noise and nuisance statutes; 
(2)  No additional license shall be required for the sale or service of alcoholic beverages in a courtyard, patio, or deck area; however, the licensee must apply for an amendment to his/her consumption on the premises license to reflect the additional service area added by the inclusion of the courtyard, patio, or deck area, and such application shall be accompanied by two copies of the plans for the proposed courtyard, patio, or deck area which shall be subject to the approval of the city manager or his/her designee; 
(3)  The courtyard, patio, or deck area shall be adequately illuminated for the safety of the patrons as determined by the building official or his/her designee; 
(4)  The licensee shall comply with all setback lines and buffer requirements of the city zoning ordinance which is in effect at the time said alcoholic beverage license application is submitted; and 
(5)  The use of a courtyard, patio, or deck as a part of the premises may be suspended or revoked by the city clerk or his/her designee if its use interferes with other permissible uses in the area surrounding the premises or if its use becomes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-81. - "Happy hour" promotions and sales. 
(a)  No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee, in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall: 
(1)  Offer any free alcoholic beverage to any person or group of persons; 
(2)  Deliver more than one alcoholic beverage to one person at one time; with the exception of any one and one-half ounce serving of a distilled spirit at such time the customer is in possession of a malt beverage. 
(3)  Encourage or permit on the licensed premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize. 
(4)  Require or allow the purchase of a second or subsequent alcoholic beverage at the same time another alcoholic beverage is purchased or before the previous alcoholic beverage has been consumed or otherwise discarded; with the exception of any one and one-half ounce serving of a distilled spirit at such time the customer is in possession of a malt beverage. 
(b)  No licensee shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the licensed premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (a). 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the delivery of a bottle of wine to the patrons of a restaurant for consumption during the course of a meal. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-82. - Sidewalk cafe. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    The following words terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this chapter, except where context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Downtown square business district means the portion of the downtown area along the following roads; (1) Robert Toombs Avenue between Allison Street and Jefferson Street; (2) Jefferson Street from Robert Toombs Avenue to Court Street; (3) Court Street from Jefferson Street to Allison Street; (4) Allison Street from Court Street to Robert Toombs Avenue; (5) Spring Street from Court Street to Robert Toombs Avenue; (6) Cheney Parkway from Court Street to Robert Toombs Avenue; (7) Public property designated as Map & Parcel number W23 061 by the county tax assessor's office; (8) Spring Street from Robert Toombs Avenue to Liberty Street.
