    Sidewalk cafe means the location and use of tables, chairs, and other associated equipment and furnishings on the public sidewalk, and operated as an extension of a licensed eating establishment or licensed alcoholic beverage premises in the downtown square business district. 
(b)  Sidewalk cafes allowed in downtown square business district; permit required. 
(1)  Sidewalk cafes shall be allowed in the area known as the downtown square business district subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  No person shall operate a sidewalk cafe without first obtaining a permit from the city building official. 
(3)  All applications for a permit shall be submitted to the city building official, and shall include the following information: 
a.  A drawing depicting the location, size and number of tables and chairs at the proposed sidewalk café location, subject to the following: 
1.  A minimum of 48 inches, clear and unobstructed, sidewalk space shall be maintained for pedestrian traffic at all times; 
2.  If a sidewalk has less than 60 inches clear width, then passing spaces at least 60 inches by 60 inches shall be located at reasonable intervals not to exceed 200 feet along the sidewalk in order to assure compliance with the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA Compliance Guide section 4.3). 
3.  The area in which a sidewalk café is located shall not extend parallel in either direction beyond the outside wall of the building in which the restraint is located. 
b.  The name, location, description, and mailing address of the business applying for the permit. 
(4)  The applicant shall procure and shall maintain comprehensive general liability, and broad form property damage insurance as shall protect applicant from claims for damages for bodily injury, including accidental death, as well as claims for property damages, which may arise from operation of a sidewalk café by the applicant or any subcontractor or by anyone directly or indirectly employed by either of them. The amount of insurance shall not be less than $1,000,000.00. 
(5)  The applicant shall provide a certificate of insurance acceptable to the city, which shall be attached to each signed application when transmitted for final approval. The city shall be named as an additional insured on all coverages. The certificates of insurance, and any subsequent renewals, shall reference the license. 
(6)  The certificates of insurance shall contain a statement that says, "Coverages afforded under the policies will not be canceled unless written notice is given to the city at least 30 days before cancellation." 
(c)  General regulations. 
(1)  A covered trash container, design to be approved by the city, with a minimum capacity of 32 gallons, containing a disposable plastic liner, shall be provided within each sidewalk café area, and shall be emptied as often as necessary to prevent overflow and other unsanitary conditions. 
(2)  Permit holders shall maintain sidewalk café areas and all equipment and furnishings in such condition as to be clean, sanitary, and safe at all times. 
(3)  Receptacles for disposal of cigarettes shall be provided for use of the customers of the sidewalk café. 
(4)  The number of patrons occupying the sidewalk café shall not be greater than the total number of chairs at each table within the sidewalk café. 
(5)  All tables, chairs, trash containers, and other associated fixtures and equipment shall be removed from the public sidewalk area at the close of business every day, unless otherwise provided for and approved in the application process. 
(d)  Regulations pertaining specifically to businesses holding alcoholic beverage licenses. 
(1)  Those businesses holding alcoholic beverage licenses shall store all alcoholic beverages inside their principal building. 
(2)  If customers choose to purchase alcoholic beverages inside the business and take them outside to the sidewalk café portion of the restraint, it shall be the responsibility of the permit holder to ensure all alcoholic beverage laws and ordinances are being complied with in the sidewalk café. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to leave the confines of the sidewalk café, except to enter the principal building containing the licensed establishment, with alcoholic beverages in their possession. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for the license holder or employees thereof to permit any person to leave the sidewalk café, except to enter the principal building containing the licensed establishment, with alcoholic beverages in their possession. 
(5)  The general regulations as set out in section 6-3 shall also apply to those restaurants holding alcoholic beverage licenses. 
(e)  Revocation, suspension. 
(1)  Any violation of this chapter that may warrant revocation of a sidewalk café permit shall be reported by any person to the city building official who shall have the power, in his discretion, to suspend the permit for a period not to exceed ten days pending a hearing before the administrative hearing officer, appointed by the city administrator on the question of whether the permit shall be revoked for cause. 
(2)  Upon a charge that there has been a violation of this chapter, the building official may order the use of the sidewalk café suspended, pending a hearing on that charge. 
(3)  Before the denial of any application for a permit, or the revocation of any existing sidewalk café permit subject to the provisions of this chapter, the applicant or permit holder, as the case may be, shall be given notice in writing from the city building official to show cause before the administrative hearing officer, appointed by the city administrator, at a time and place specified therein not less than three days nor more than ten days from the date of service of the notice, why such application should not be denied or why such permit should not be revoked, as the case may be, stating grounds therefore, and at the appointed time and place the applicant or permit holder shall have an opportunity to show cause, if any exist, why such application should not be denied or such permit revoked, after which the administrative hearing officer shall take such actions as he or she in his or her judgement and discretion shall deem warranted under the facts. All decisions of the administrative hearing officer shall be in writing with reasons therefore stated and mailed or delivered to the applicant, permit holder or person in charge of the place of business if the permit holder cannot be located. In addition, at any hearing as provided herein, the party afforded the hearing shall have the opportunity to present evidence and cross-examine opposing witnesses. 
(4)  Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the administrative hearing officer to deny an application for a permit applied for under the provisions of this chapter or the revocation or suspension of a permit, shall have the right of certiorari to the superior court from the decision of the administrative hearing officer, as provided by law. 
(f)  Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-82-6-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PACKAGE MALT BEVERAGE AND WINE; LICENSE REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 6-90. - Wine tasting. 
    Persons who are licensed by the state and by the city to sell wine for off-premises consumption and that derive at least 51 percent of their daily revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed to conduct wine tastings on premises pursuant to all applicable department of revenue regulations as such regulations may be amended from time to time with the following additional restrictions: 
(1)  Wine tastings may only be conducted during the hours which wine may be sold for off-premises consumption; 
(2)  No person may participate in a wine tasting unless that person is 21 years of age or older; 
(3)  Any person participating in a wine tasting must pay a fee to participate that is equal to or greater than the pro rata wholesale cost of the portion size of each serving of wine that is provided to be tasted; 
(4)  The portion size of the serving of the wines to be tasted shall not exceed four fluid ounces per serving; and 
(5)  The licensee may not serve any person more than 16 ounce samples of wine in any one calendar day. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-91. - Brewery production and sales. 
(a)  Brewery production and sales. A license for on-premises production and on-premises sale of malt beverages may be authorized by the said mayor and city council to persons otherwise entitled to a brewery production and sales of malt beverages license, provided the following conditions are met: 
(1)  All brewing operations by a brewery shall be conducted within an enclosed building. Production space shall not exceed 15,000 square feet. 
(2)  All state regulations relating to the manufacture, sale, and distribution of beer, as revised from time to time, promulgated by the state revenue department, are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this chapter as if fully set out in this section. 
(b)  Consumption on the premises . Brewery shall be permitted to serve malt beverages produced at the brewer's licensed premises for consumption on the premises, subject to the following restrictions: 
a.  Total sales of malt beverages for consumption on the premises and for consumption off the premises at the brewer's licensed premises shall be less than 3,000 barrels in each calendar year in which the licensee is permitted. For purposes of this section, barrel shall be defined in accordance with state law. 
(c)  Consumption off the premises . 
a.  Total sales of malt beverages for consumption on the premises and for consumption off the premises at the brewer's licensed premises shall be less than 3,000 barrels in each calendar year in which the licensee is permitted. For purposes of this section, barrel shall be defined in accordance with state law. 
b.  Any sales of malt beverages shall not exceed a maximum of 288 ounces per consumer per day. 
c.  Retail sales of growlers in compliance with this section shall be authorized for licensees under this section. The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a package as contemplated by O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-26, and 3-4-25, or other provisions of this section. Growlers may be filled from either kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler for malt beverages not produced on-site or by malt beverages produced on-site, subject to and counting towards the 3,000 barrel limitation cited previously. Only professionally sanitized and sealed growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale. Each growler must be securely sealed with a tamperproof plastic cap and removed from the premises in its original sealed condition. Consumption on the premises is strictly prohibited. However, samples of tap beers may be made available, but shall not exceed more than one ounce nor shall any one individual be offered more than three samples within a 24-hour period. 
(d)  Samples. Samples of tap beers may be made available, but shall not exceed more than one ounce nor shall any one individual be offered more than three samples within a 24-hour period. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for a brewery licensee or any employee thereof to be on duty at the licensed premises in an intoxicated condition. "Intoxication" shall be defined as when a licensee's or employee's alcohol concentration is 0.08 grams or more at any time while on duty. For purposes of this section, "on duty" shall mean being paid any salary, wage, or remuneration of any kind for services rendered during the time he or she is on the premises; on the licensed premises for the benefit of or at the direction of the licensee or its management (other than as a customer, patron, or guest) or taking a break during periods of any on-duty employment. 
(f)  Subject to the provisions in this chapter, a brewery licensee or employee thereof shall be permitted to taste malt beverages at the licensed premises for quality control or educational purposes only. Such tastings shall not exceed four ounces in volume per hour and eight ounces in volume total within a calendar day. 
(g)  No holder of a license authorizing the sale of malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits at retail in the city, nor any agent or employee of the licensee, shall knowingly sell or provide malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits to a person confined in any jail, penal institution, correctional facility or other lawful place of confinement. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale, any malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits where such person does not have a license from the city to sell or possess for sale such beverages. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-92. - Sale of malt beverages in growlers. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided for within this chapter, the sale of malt beverages in growlers shall only be allowed in establishments that are licensed for the sale of malt beverages for off-premises consumption and that derive at least 51 percent of their daily revenue from the sale of malt beverages. 
(b)  The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a package as contemplated by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-26 or other provisions of this chapter, provided that after the growler is filled the growler must be sealed on the licensed premises with a tamper-proof plastic cap and may not thereafter be opened or consumed on the premises. Licensees or employees of the licensed establishment may fill or refill growlers with draft malt beverages at a licensed location for retail package sales as provided herein in a growler not smaller than 12 ounces in volume and not to exceed 64 ounces in volume. 
(c)  No person shall consume malt beverages from a growler on any licensed premises. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-93-6-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PACKAGE DISTILLED SPIRITS; LICENSE REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATION 

Sec. 6-100. - Applicability of chapter to those businesses operating both the retail sale of distilled spirits and package malt beverages and wine. 
    For licensees who wish to operate a business that conducts both the retail sale of distilled spirits and package malt beverages and wine, in the case of conflict, the provisions of this chapter regulating the sale of distilled spirits shall prevail, and compliance with those provisions, rather than the provisions applicable to the license permitting the sale of package malt beverages and wine, is required. The applicant shall be required to complete the application(s) required by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-101. - Separation of alcoholic beverages from nonalcoholic merchandise. 
    All holders of licenses under this article shall separate alcoholic beverages from their nonalcoholic merchandise so that the alcoholic beverages may be closed off from the rest of the premises at all times when sale thereof is prohibited, and the same shall be so closed off during the prohibited times for sale. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-102. - Consumption prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on premises licensed for the sale of package alcoholic beverages. For the purpose of this section only, "premises" shall include the parking area immediately adjoining the premises licensed for the sale of package alcoholic beverages and available for the use of the customers of the licensed premises, whether or not the same are owned or leased by the license holder. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises or to sell unsealed (broken) alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-103. - Sale or delivery off premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee of a retail establishment permitted to sell distilled spirits hereunder to make deliveries of any alcoholic beverages by the package beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-104-6-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - WHOLESALERS: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 6-110. - Requirements of wholesalers generally. 
    All wholesale dealers or distributors shall be licensed by the state revenue department and shall comply with all laws and regulations of the state revenue department before they sell or deliver any alcoholic beverages in the city. Deliveries and sales shall be made only to retailers licensed under the provisions of this article and all deliveries shall be made in conveyances owned and operated by such wholesale dealers or distributors. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-111. - Other licenses. 
    The licenses and taxes provided for in this article are not levied in lieu of any other license fees or taxes that may be levied upon licensees, but are in addition thereto. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-112. - Issuance of licenses limited to designated area. 
    No license permitting the wholesale distribution of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any applicant proposing to locate within the city unless the premises are located in an area of the city that is properly zoned for such use. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-113. - Regulations governing retail storage. 
    All licensed retailers shall store all alcoholic beverages on the premises for which the license was issued and at no other place. No wholesaler shall store for any retail dealer those alcoholic beverages that have been purchased. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-114. - Consumption prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on premises licensed for the wholesale sale of alcoholic beverages. For the purpose of this section only, "premises" shall include the parking area immediately adjoining the wholesaler's premises and available for the use of the customers of the licensed premises, whether or not the same are owned or leased by the license holder. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises or to sell unsealed (broken) alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-115-6-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ALCOHOL IN PUBLIC PLACES, BROWN-BAGGING 

Sec. 6-120. - Alcoholic beverages in public places. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation licensed to sell alcoholic beverages shall permit any person to remove from such premises any alcoholic beverage in any open container. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to nor shall it affect the sale of or possession of a partially consumed bottle of wine purchased with a meal from a restaurant and resealed as permitted by O.C.G.A. §§ 3-6-4 and 40-6-253(2). 
(c)  This section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  For events that are sponsored or organized by the city, but only for malt beverage and wine and where alcohol is obtained from a participating business in the downtown entertainment district, and is contained in and consumed from an approved clear plastic container, and where the person consuming or possessing such alcohol is wearing an approved wristband when designated an open container event. 
a.  For the purposes of this chapter only, the downtown entertainment district is defined as follows: The center of downtown Washington bordered by Robert Toombs Avenue on the south, by North Jefferson Street on the east, by Court Street on the north, and by Allison Street on the west. This is a specifically authorized and pedestrian oriented area of the city that allows those establishments with valid consumption on premises licenses within such area to dispense and/or serve an alcoholic beverage for "carry out" purposes, provided all other laws, rules, and ordinances are followed. 
b.  One drink per person on street limit. Within the downtown entertainment district any establishment licensed to sell alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises is authorized to dispense an alcoholic beverage in a clear plastic cup for removal from the premises; provided however that no person shall remove more than one such alcoholic from the licensed premises at a time. 
c.  Size limited to a maximum of 16 ounces. Within the downtown entertainment district, no container in which an alcoholic beverage is dispensed and removed from the licensed premises shall exceed 16 fluid ounces in size. No person shall hold in their possession on the streets and sidewalks, in parks and squares, or in other public places within a carry district any open alcoholic beverage container which exceeds 16 fluid ounces in size. 
d.  Drinking from can, bottle, or glass prohibited. It shall be unlawful within the downtown entertainment district for any person to drink or attempt to drink any alcoholic beverage from any can, bottle, or glass, or to possess in an open can, bottle or glass any alcoholic beverage on the streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way, or parking lots whether public or private. 
e.  Consumption limited to the downtown entertainment district. No alcoholic beverage purchased pursuant to this provision may be consumed outside of the downtown entertainment district, upon any sidewalk, adjacent to a church, school or park (unless specifically authorized by the city) or upon any private property without the express written consent of the property owners. 
f.  Consumption limited to lawful hours of operation. Alcoholic beverage purchased within the downtown entertainment district shall not be consumed within the downtown entertainment district on the streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way, and/or parking lots, whether public or private, prior to 11:00 a.m., or later than 11 p.m. 
(2)  For events sponsored or organized by the city and that are open to the general public on city owned property, when designated a BYOB event, attendees may have in their possession no more than 72 ounces of malt beverages and/or 50 ounces of wine not otherwise purchased pursuant to subsection (1) above. Any such malt beverages and/ or wine may be consumed on city property only. No glass containers shall be allowed, and coolers shall be limited to no more than 24 inches along any dimension. Any such coolers must remain in the possession of an adult at all times. All empty containers shall be removed and/or properly disposed of by the person consuming its contents. These provisions notwithstanding, the city may elect not to allow attendees to have in their possession malt beverages and/or wine not otherwise purchased pursuant to subsection (1) above. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-121. - Bring your own bottle "brown-bagging" prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any alcoholic beverage (brown bag) onto any property unless such person is the lawful owner of said property, unless the occupational tax on said property has been paid in full and is current, and unless the alcoholic beverage is for the owner's personal use. This restriction shall not be applicable to residential or government-owned property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any corporation, partnership, individual or other entity who maintains a business which is subject to any of the occupational tax provisions of the city or is specifically exempted from occupational taxes as provided for in the city occupational tax ordinance to knowingly allow a person to violate the provisions of subsection (a) on their property. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to, nor shall it affect any business in possession of a bottle house license in accordance with section 6-82. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-122. - Permitted locations and special events. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverages shall be dispensed, distributed, poured or served at any special event location, premises, or building in the city except as set out in this chapter unless otherwise provided for under this chapter; 
(b)  The owner or lessee of a location at which alcoholic beverages are to be furnished and served at a private function or special event by a person at a location not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter shall first obtain a qualifying location permit designating such location as a "permitted location." Such qualifying location permit shall be good for the calendar year in which it is issued and may be renewed annually as set forth in this chapter. Thereafter, the person organizing the private function or special event to be held at a permitted location must apply for and obtain a "special event permit" as set forth in section 6-123 of this chapter. The cost of such permits shall be set by the city council as set out in section 6-36. The requirements of section 6-122 shall be met by an applicant for a permitted location license. 
(c)  To qualify as a "permitted location," the location, premises or building shall not fail to meet all the minimum distance requirements set out in section 6-122, and shall not fail to meet all requirements of the building inspector, the fire marshal, and the planning and zoning department for an on-premises pouring outlet, and shall possess a permit as a "permitted location" pursuant to this chapter. The applicant for a qualifying location permit shall submit a plat of survey prepared by a state registered land surveyor showing the distances set forth in this chapter with the application for the qualifying location permit. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish and serve alcoholic beverages at a private function or special event at a permitted location unless food is also served at the private function or special event. 
(e)  Alcoholic beverages furnished and served at a private function or special event may be consumed only on the premises; and may not be removed from the premises in an open container. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any alcoholic beverages to be sold at a private function or special event, i.e. "no cash bar" sales will be permitted unless the permitted location also holds an on premises consumption license for alcoholic beverages. 
(g)  Locations, premises or buildings for which an on-premises consumption license has been issued pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed a "permitted location" under this section without further application; however, all rules, laws, and ordinances must be followed. 
(h)  The "permitted location" licensee shall be responsible for any violation of this chapter which occurs at the "permitted location" whether by the licensee's employees or agents, a caterer or their employees or agents, or a lessee or invitee of the licensee, their lessee or invitees or any of their employees or agents. 
(i)  The person holding the private function or special event, and not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter must purchase and furnish the alcoholic beverages. 
(j)  The serving, without sale, of alcoholic beverages at a special event in a permitted location for a special event not otherwise required to be licensed or licensed hereunder for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall be only permitted during the times for sales of alcoholic beverages as set forth in section 6-13 of this chapter for premises licensed for consumption on the premises only. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-123. - Special event permits. 
(a)  In order to serve wine, and/or beer and malt beverages, and/or distilled spirits at a private function or special event, at a permitted location, the person organizing the private function or special event shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply to the city for a "special event permit." The application shall include the name and business address of any caterer providing food service for the private function or special event, the date, time and location of the event, which location must be a permitted location as set forth in section 6-122 or otherwise exempt as set forth under this chapter; 
(2)  Pay the cost of such permit as set forth in section 6-36 of this chapter. 
    If the application meets all of the requirements of this chapter, the city clerk shall issue the special event permit. If the city clerk finds that the application does not meet the requirements of this chapter and denies the special event permit, the applicant may appeal to the city council within five days of the date of the denial. 
(b)  The "special event permit" shall be maintained at the site of the private function or special event during the hours alcoholic beverages are served. 
(c)  The person holding the private function or special event, and not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter, must purchase the alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  The "special event permit" licensee shall be responsible for any violation of this chapter which occurs at the event whether by the licensee's employees or agents, invitee of the licensee or invitee of the invitee of the licensee. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-124. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to an event held for business development, or charitable purposes, by a bona fide nonprofit organization, at which alcoholic beverages are served, by a person or organization not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter, to members and invited guests of such persons or organizations holding the event at a permitted location or at a location not otherwise required to be permitted pursuant to this chapter, provided that the person or organization purchased and served the alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to an event held at a private residence at which alcoholic beverages are purchased and served by a person not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter to invited guests of such person, provided that the person holding the event purchases the alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the times for sales of alcoholic beverages set forth in section 6-13 herein, shall apply to the exceptions set forth in paragraphs (a) and (b) of this section, except that serving without sale of alcoholic beverages at an event described in paragraph (a) or (b) at a location not otherwise required to be licensed, or licensed hereunder for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises only shall be shall be permitted on Sunday between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-125. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person or persons found by the building official to be in violation of the above sections having to do with special event permits will be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  The first offense will result in a written warning and request for immediate corrective action. 
(2)  The second offense will result in a suspension of the qualified location permit for up to 90 days as determined in the sole discretion of the building official. 
(3)  The third offense will result in permanent revocation of the qualified location permit. 
(4)  The aforementioned penalties are determined in the sole discretion of the building official, but, can be appealed to the city administrator within ten days of the violation. 
(5)  Any violation of state law will be reported to the proper authorities. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-126-6-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - AGE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 6-130. - Age requirements on licensed premises. 
(a)  The age requirements for employees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Package alcoholic beverage and wholesale licensees: Except as provided in this subsection, no wholesale dealer or package store licensee shall allow any employee under the age of 18 years to sell, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages. The provisions of this subsection shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in grocery stores, supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries or drug stores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages that are sold for consumption off the premises; however, the licensee shall ensure that said person under 18 years of age shall be under direct supervision of a person who shall be both employed by said establishment and who shall be over the age of 21 years of age and shall be on-site at all times during which the underage employee is working. 
(2)  Consumption on the premises licensees and caterers: No consumption on the premises licensee or licensed caterer shall allow any employee under the age of 18 years to dispense, sell, serve, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages. 
a.  The subsection shall not prohibit the employment of persons under the above ages on licensed premises where such persons do not dispense, sell, serve, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages. 
b.  This section shall not apply to those employees who clear tableware between customers, also known as "busboys," nor shall it apply to those employees who are cooks or dishwashers. 
c.  Those employees of a consumption on the premises licensee and licensed caterers who are 18 years of age but younger than 21 years of age shall be under direct supervision of a person who shall be both employed by said establishment and who shall be over the age of 21 years of age and shall be present at all times during which the underage employee is working. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-131-6-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - STORAGE AND LABELING OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 6-140. - Storage on unlicensed premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation not holding an alcoholic beverage license granted by the city to store any alcoholic beverages on the grounds of any retail establishment, excluding alcoholic beverages for personal consumption, in accordance with all applicable provisions of law. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-141. - Keeping or storing without appropriate license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating under a license for the sale of malt beverages or wine or both to store or have therein any distilled spirits without an appropriate license. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-142. - Regulations governing retail storage. 
    All alcoholic beverages shall be available at all times for inspection by the chief of police of the city or his/her designee. Any alcoholic beverages found in any retailer's stock that is purchased from another retail dealer or any alcoholic beverages that were sold or distributed by a wholesaler who is not licensed in accordance with the laws of the state to make sales and deliveries in the state shall be subject to immediate confiscation and disposal in accordance with applicable law. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-143. - Misrepresentation of alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for licensees or their agents to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any manner misrepresent the quantity, quality, or brand names of any alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-144-6-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION; APPEAL HEARINGS; PENALTIES 

Sec. 6-150. - Emergency suspension situations. 
    The city clerk or his/her designee is hereby authorized to suspend any license issued hereunder for any emergency situation such as civil disorders or natural disasters or in any situation that the city clerk deems such immediate suspension necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the citizens of the city, and such suspension may be made effective immediately and shall remain in force until the license is reinstated by the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-151. - Removal of signs. 
    When any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages is revoked, all signs indicating that such beverages may be sold or purchased shall immediately be removed from both inside and outside the place of business. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-152. - Appeal hearings. 
    No license or permit shall be denied, suspended, or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-154. - Denial of alcoholic beverage license; appeals. 
(a)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall provide written notice to an alcoholic beverage license applicant of the decision to deny said alcoholic beverage license application. Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such action and shall notify the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  An applicant may appeal the denial of an alcoholic beverage license application by providing written notification to the city administrator at city hall within ten calendar days of the denial of the alcoholic beverage license application. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(c)  In order to defray administrative costs, the appeal must be accompanied by a filing fee of $500.00. If, following the administrative hearing, the city clerk or his/her designee issues an alcoholic beverage license to the applicant, then the $500.00 filing fee shall be applied towards the cost of the alcoholic beverage license. 
(d)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall set an administrative hearing date that shall occur within 30 calendar days of the filing of the appeal request. Notice of said administrative hearing shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage license applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage license applicant's application. 
(e)  At the administrative hearing, the alcoholic beverage license applicant is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The city administrator or his/her designee shall determine whether the denial of the alcoholic beverage license application is justified using a preponderance of the evidence standard. 
(f)  The city administrator or his/her designee shall consider the following factors in determining whether to uphold the denial of an application: 
(1)  Compliance with the criminal history requirements; 
(2)  Compliance with the requirements of this chapter; 
(3)  The history of and facts relating to previous violations of this chapter; 
(4)  Non-alcohol related violations of this Code; 
(5)  Violations of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(6)  Documented efforts at avoiding violations of this chapter, this Code or state law; 
(7)  Community involvement; and 
(8)  Any other objective and relevant facts. 
(g)  The city administrator or his/her designee, after hearing evidence, shall have the authority to uphold, modify or overturn the previous decision. The city administrator or his/her designee shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the administrative hearing. All decisions by the city administrator or his/her designee shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage license applicant at the address set forth in the license application. 
(h)  Any applicant may appeal the city administrator or his/her designee's decision to the mayor and city council within ten calendar days of the date that the adverse decision is issued by the city administrator. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the clerk of the city. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(i)  In order to defray administrative costs, the appeal must be accompanied by an additional filing fee of $500.00. If, following the administrative hearing, the mayor and city council issue an alcoholic beverage license to the applicant, then the $1,000.00 in total filing fees shall be applied towards the cost of the alcoholic beverage license. 
(j)  The mayor and city council shall set a hearing date within 30 calendar days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage license applicant's application. At the hearing, the applicant is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The city administrator or his/her representative may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial. The decision of the city administrator or his/her designee shall not be set aside unless the mayor and city council finds it to be: 
(1)  Contrary to law or ordinances; 
(2)  Unsupported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole; or 
(3)  Unreasonable. 
(k)  All decisions of the mayor and city council shall be final. The mayor and city council shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the hearing. All decisions by the city council shall be in writing and shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage license applicant at the address set forth in the applicable license application. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-155. - Administrative penalties and appeal hearings for alcoholic beverage handling permit holders. 
(a)  Upon notice of violation of these ordinances, the city clerk or his/her designee shall provide written notice to an alcoholic beverage handling permit holder of the intention to impose one or more of the following administrative penalties: 
(1)  Suspend their permit; 
(2)  Revoke their permit; 
(3)  Impose an administrative monetary penalty not to exceed $1,000.00; or 
(4)  Convey a warning for any violation of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
    Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the facts supporting such violation, shall set forth the proposed administrative penalty, and shall notify the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder of their right to appeal under the provisions of this article. Said written notification shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address set forth in the applicable application, and a copy of said written notification shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(b)  An alcoholic beverage handling permit holder may appeal the proposed administrative penalty by providing written notification to the city clerk within ten calendar days of the date that said written notification was hand delivered to the premises. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(c)  In the event that the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder does not timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty(ies), then said alcoholic beverage handling permit holder shall be deemed to agree with said proposed administrative penalty(ies). Further, in the event that said proposed administrative penalty include the imposition of an administrative monetary penalty, said administrative monetary penalty shall be due and owing to the city within five calendar days of the date of hand delivery of the written notification. The failure to timely pay any administrative monetary penalties shall subject the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder to further administrative penalties. 
(d)  In the event that the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder does timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty, then the city clerk shall set an administrative hearing date that shall occur within 30 calendar days of the filing of the appeal request. Notice of said administrative hearing shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said written notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(e)  At the administrative hearing, the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The city clerk shall determine whether the proposed administrative penalty of the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder as set forth in the written notification is justified using a preponderance of the evidence standard. 
(f)  The city clerk shall consider the following factors in determining whether the proposed administrative penalty of the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder as set forth in the written notification is justified: 
(1)  Compliance with the criminal history requirements; 
(2)  The history of and facts relating to previous violations of this chapter; 
(3)  Non-alcohol related violations of this Code; 
(4)  Violations of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(5)  Documented efforts at avoiding violations of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(6)  Community involvement; and 
(7)  Any other objective and relevant facts. 
(g)  The city clerk, after hearing evidence, shall have the authority to uphold, modify or overturn the proposed administrative penalty. The city clerk shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the hearing. All decisions by the city clerk shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address set forth in the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(h)  Any alcoholic beverage handling permit holder may appeal the city clerk's decision to the city administrator within ten calendar days of the date that the adverse decision is hand delivered to the premises. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the clerk of the city. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(i)  The city administrator shall set a hearing date within 30 calendar days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. At the hearing, the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The city clerk or his/her representative may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the imposition of the administrative penalty. The decision of the city clerk shall not be set aside unless the city administrator finds it to be: 
(1)  Contrary to law or ordinances; 
(2)  Unsupported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole; or 
(3)  Unreasonable. 
(j)  All decisions of the city administrator shall be final. The city administrator shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the hearing. All decisions by the city administrator shall be in writing and shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address set forth in the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-156. - Administrative penalties and appeal hearings for license holders. 
(a)  Upon notice of violation of these ordinances, the city clerk or his/her designee shall provide written notice to a license holder of the intention to impose one or more of the following administrative penalties: 
(1)  Suspend their license; 
(2)  Revoke their license; 
(3)  Impose an administrative monetary penalty not to exceed $5,000.00; or 
(4)  Convey a warning for any violation of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
    Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the facts supporting such violation, shall set forth the proposed administrative penalty, and shall notify the license holder of their right to appeal under the provisions of this article. Said written notification shall be mailed to the license holder at the address set forth in the applicable application, and a copy of said written notification shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(b)  A license holder may appeal the proposed administrative penalty by providing written notification to the city administrator at city hall within ten calendar days of the date that said written notification was hand delivered to the premises. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(c)  In the event that the license holder does not timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty, then said license holder shall be deemed to agree with said proposed administrative penalty. Further, in the event that said proposed administrative penalty include the imposition of an administrative monetary penalty, said administrative monetary penalty shall be due and owing to the city within five calendar days of the date of hand delivery. The failure to timely pay any administrative monetary penalties shall subject the license holder to further administrative penalties. 
(d)  In the event that the license holder does timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty(ies), then the city administrator or his/her designee shall set an administrative hearing date that shall occur within 30 calendar days of the filing of the appeal request. Notice of said administrative hearing shall be mailed to the license holder at the address shown on the license holder's application and a copy of said written notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(e)  At the administrative hearing, the license holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The city administrator or his/her designee shall determine whether the proposed administrative penalty of the license holder as set forth in the written notification is justified using a preponderance of the evidence standard. 
(f)  The city administrator or his/her designee shall consider the following factors in determining whether the proposed administrative penalty(ies) of the license holder as set forth in the written notification is justified: 
(1)  Compliance with the criminal history requirements; 
(2)  The history of and facts relating to previous violations of this chapter; 
(3)  Non-alcohol related violations of this Code; 
(4)  Violations of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(5)  Documented efforts at avoiding violations of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(6)  Training history of employees; 
(7)  Community involvement; and 
(8)  Any other objective and relevant facts. 
(g)  The city administrator or his/her designee, after hearing evidence, shall have the authority to uphold, modify or overturn the city clerk or his/her designee's proposed administrative penalty(ies). The city administrator or his/her designee shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the hearing. All decisions by the city administrator or his/her designee shall be mailed to the license holder at the address set forth in the license holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(h)  Any license holder may appeal the city administrator or his/her designee's decision to the mayor and city council within ten calendar days of the date that the adverse decision is hand delivered to the premises. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the clerk of the city. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(i)  In order to defray administrative costs, the appeal shall be accompanied by a filing fee of $500.00. If, following the administrative hearing, the city administrator or his/her designee's decision is modified or overturned, then the $500.00 filing fee shall be refunded. The mayor and city council shall set a hearing date within 30 calendar days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage license applicant's application and a copy of said notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. At the hearing, the license holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The city administrator or his/her representative may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the imposition of the administrative penalty. The decision of the city administrator or his/her designee shall not be set aside unless the mayor and city council finds it to be: 
(1)  Contrary to law or ordinances; 
(2)  Unsupported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole; or 
(3)  Unreasonable. 
(j)  All decisions of the mayor and city council shall be final. The mayor and city council shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of delivery of the hearing. All decisions by the city council shall be in writing and shall be mailed to the license holder at the address set forth in the license holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-157. - Ordinance violation penalties. 
(a)  Upon conviction in the municipal court of any violation of this chapter, the person so convicted shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a period of not more than six months, or both. Each act in violation and each day upon which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In the event of a suspension of a license is imposed upon any licensed establishment where a violation of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23 has occurred by employees, managers, or owners, the licensed establishment shall be required to post signs, to be provided by the city clerk or his/her designee, on the exterior doors of the establishment which contains the following language: "An employee or owner of this store has violated state law by selling alcoholic beverages to a minor" for the period of the suspension imposed by the city. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Secs. 6-158, 6-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - TEMPORARY SPECIAL EVENT LICENSE 

Sec. 6-160. - Responsible party designation. 
    A bona fide nonprofit civic organization wishing to apply for and receive a temporary special event license shall designate a responsible party who shall be a member in good standing of said bona fide nonprofit civic organization. The responsible party shall make the application for said temporary special event license, and the temporary special event license shall be issued in the responsible party's name on behalf of the bona fide nonprofit civic organization. The responsible party shall be individually responsible for any and all claims, losses or liability arising out of or connected with the temporary special event, whether in contract or in tort (including negligence), law or equity. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-161. - Temporary special event license application forms. 
(a)  All bona fide nonprofit civic organizations desiring to receive a temporary special event license shall make application on a form prescribed by the city clerk or his/her designee. No application will be processed until the responsible party has completed the required interview with the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(b)  The application shall include, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  The name and address of the responsible party; 
(2)  The date, address, beginning time and ending time of the temporary special event; 
(3)  A description of the premises at which said temporary special event shall occur (said description shall be an aerial map, a description of the metes and bounds, or other such specific descriptions as will allow the city to determine the boundaries of said premises). 
(4)  A copy of the 501(c)(3) letter issued by the IRS for the bona fide nonprofit civic organization; 
(5)  A copy of the by-laws and corporate charter from the secretary of state's office for the bona fide nonprofit civic organization; 
(6)  A copy of the special event non-profit permit issued by the state for said temporary special event; 
(7)  A resolution issued by the bona fide nonprofit civic organization authorizing the temporary special event; and 
(8)  Written documentation evidencing a partnership between the bona fide nonprofit civic organization and an alcoholic beverage license holder who has been granted an off-premises consumption license. 
(c)  The responsible party shall furnish data, information and records as required by the city clerk or his/her designee and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the application to be denied. 
(d)  A complete set of fingerprints of the responsible party for a new temporary special event license shall be required. 
(1)  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled "Dissemination of information to public agencies, political subdivisions, authorities, and instrumentalities." 
(2)  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive a temporary special event license shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for a temporary special event license. The responsible party shall be required to provide fingerprints each time an application is submitted, unless that same responsible party has already provided fingerprints to the city within the same calendar year. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the city obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (F.B.I.). 
(3)  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
a.  The city is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
b.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all Georgia laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
c.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
d.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
(d)  Administration; fees; procedures. 
(1)  The applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints, which may be taken by the county sheriff's department or may be taken at any Georgia applicant processing services location, so long as the applicant registers in such a manner that allows the county sheriff's department to receive the criminal history results. 
(2)  The applicant shall bear the cost of the electronic fingerprinting submission services set by the Georgia applicant processing services and an administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the city, which shall be the maximum allowed by statute, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the county sheriff's department. 
(3)  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the city will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the sheriff's department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the F.B.I. for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the F.B.I. is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the F.B.I. check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the sheriff's department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the OBI and F.B.I. where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
(4)  In compliance with federal law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a "fitness determination," the city will decide whether the applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
(5)  A person who has consented to the city for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the city at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to Georgia records and/or the F.B.I. concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(e)  All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Sec. 6-162. - Temporary special event license. 
(a)  In order to distribute or sell alcoholic beverages at a temporary special event, a bona fide nonprofit civic organization shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply to the city for an alcoholic beverage temporary special event license; and 
(2)  Pay an alcoholic beverage temporary special event license fee according to the schedule approved from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall review the responsible party's application and supporting documentation and shall evaluate the application based upon the following factors: 
(1)  The city clerk or his/her designee's perception of whether the event can be conducted safely; 
(2)  Whether the county sheriff's department can adequately provide security for said temporary special event; 
(3)  The number of people anticipated to be attending the temporary special event; 
(4)  The geographic location of the premises upon which the temporary special event will be held; 
(5)  The impact of the temporary special event on surrounding businesses or residents; and 
(6)  Whether the responsible party has failed to meet any other criteria specified by this chapter or state law. 
(c)  The city clerk or his/her designee shall have discretion when evaluating the aforementioned factors and shall either approve or deny, in writing, said temporary special event license application. 
(d)  All temporary special event license applications must be submitted at least 30 calendar days prior to the planned special event. 
(e)  No more than two temporary special event licenses may be issued to a bona fide nonprofit civic organization in any one calendar year. 
(f)  A list of all donated alcoholic beverages from the wholesaler must be maintained by the temporary special event license holder at all times. 
(g)  The restrictions set forth in the section 6-13, hours of operation, shall apply to all sales of alcoholic beverages at authorized temporary special events. 
(Ord. of 8-14-2017) 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 26; health and sanitation, ch. 38; mosquito control, § 38-96 et seq.; R-1 Agriculture residential district, § 90-66 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Bird sanctuary. 
(a)  The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob birds' nests or wildlife nests. However, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property in the opinion of the mayor and council, the mayor and council shall take whatever steps it deems necessary to abate the nuisance or menace. 
(Code 1989, § 4-1) 
Sec. 10-2. - Vicious animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or other person to maintain or harbor within the city a manifestly vicious animal unless the animal is securely, but humanely, confined or restrained in such manner as to prevent the animal from attacking or biting a person or another animal. It shall be prima facie evidence of viciousness if an animal, without provocation, fiercely attacks or bites persons or animals not on the owner's premises. 
(Code 1989, § 4-3; Ord. of 3-9-2009) 
State Law reference- Liability for damages caused by vicious animals, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7. 
Sec. 10-3. - Reserved. 
Sec. 10-4. - Poultry houses and barns. 
    No commercial poultry house or structure for the keeping of any livestock or fowl for commercial purposes shall be constructed in the city limits. For purposes of this section "commercial purpose" shall mean any purpose which is performed in conjunction with the operation of a for-profit business or enterprise. 
(Ord. of 4-28-2009; Res. of 6-11-2018, § 1) 
Sec. 10-5. - Animals in residential districts. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the intent of this section to permit certain uses in residential zoning districts which involve the keeping of limited numbers of domestic animals or pets where it is recognized that such areas are changing form agricultural to suburban residential in character. This section is further intended to minimize problems which may arise from such animal uses and to provide suitable standards for protection of health, safety, welfare and preservation of residential zoning districts from indiscriminate raising of animals. These restrictions apply to districts R-1, R-1A, R-2 R-3, H1, RMH, R-3A, and R-3B and shall be subject to all state and local health codes. 
(b)  Uses permitted. 
(1)  Livestock. Horses, cows, pigs, ponies, donkeys and other domestic livestock may be kept, raised or bred for home use and enjoyment provided that only one such animal shall be permitted for each 15,000 square feet of land area and shall be adequately contained within the property, and do not become a nuisance as defined by the Code of Ordinances for the City of Washington, or state law. 
(2)  Domestic pets. Cats, dogs, rabbits or other generally recognized domestic pets may be kept or bred by persons residing on the property for their use and enjoyment, and do not become a nuisance as defined by the Code of Ordinances for the City of Washington, or state law. 
(3)  Fowl. Ducks, quail, chickens, turkeys, squabs, pheasant, etc. may be raised for home use provided such fowl are adequately contained within the property, and do not become a nuisance as defined by the Code of Ordinances for the City of Washington, or state law. A flock for home use will be limited to 12 fowl total. 
(4)  Number of animals within a residence. This ordinance is not intended to limit the number of animals a person can keep within a residence; however, the residence must not become a nuisance, violate building or health codes, the Code of Ordinances for the City of Washington, or state or federal law. 
(5)  Distance from property lines. Notwithstanding any provision in this section to the contrary, buildings or other structures which are located in residential districts and are used to accommodate or restrain animals noted in subsections (b)(1) and (3) of this section shall be located no less than 50 feet from all property lines. 
(c)  Uses prohibited. The keeping, breeding or training of any animals or fowl for monetary gain or profit shall be deemed a commercial business and only be permitted in the allowed zoning districts and expressly prohibited districts R-1, R-1A, R-2 R-3, H1, RMH, R-3A, and R-3B. 
(Ord. of 4-28-2009; Res. of 6-11-2018, § 1) 
Secs. 10-6-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-31. - Prohibited in certain premises. 
(a)  Except as provided in O.C.G.A. § 30-4-1, et seq. and the Americans with Disabilities Act, it shall be unlawful for any person owning, having in charge or having control of any dog to carry the dog or to permit the dog to enter or be carried inside any grocery store, drugstore, restaurant, café, boardinghouse, hotel, fruit stand, warehouse, refreshment stand, or any place where food, medicines, groceries, or merchandise of any kind intended for human consumption is sold, prepared, eaten or dispensed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, manager or other person in charge of such premises to knowingly permit the violation of this section. It shall also be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of such premises to permit the placing of dogs in buggies, carts or containers of any kind used and intended for carting merchandise and food stuffs in such places of business. 
(Code 1989, § 4-25; Ord. of 2-14-2015; Res. of 6-11-2018, § 1) 
Sec. 10-32. - Care and treatment of dogs. 
(a)  Adequate shelter. All dog owners shall at all times provide said dog with shelter adequate to reasonably protect it from the elements. Such shelter shall, at a minimum, be sufficient to keep the animal dry, protected from adverse weather conditions, and at a temperature level that is healthful to the dog. Said shelter shall further be kept free of accumulated waste and debris so that the dog can walk or lie down without coming in contact with any such waste or debris, and shall have a suitable method of draining so as to eliminate excess water or moisture. 
(b)  Adequate food and water. All dog owners shall at all times provide said dog with an adequate, fresh, and sanitary supply of food and water. 
(c)  Authority to remove dog. If the city or its designee finds a dog is without the appropriate provisions stated in (a) or (b), then the city is authorized to direct the owner that such provisions be immediately provided, or the city has the authority to remove the dog for its well-being. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person to fail to comply with such order to provide the appropriate provisions after being instructed to do so. 
(Ord. of 2-14-2015) 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted February 14, 2015, renumbered § 10-32 as § 10-33. 
Sec. 10-33. - Running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having possession or control or care of a dog to allow the dog to stray or run at large upon the streets, playgrounds, or other public places or private properties of others within the city. A dog shall at all times be restrained or enclosed upon the premises of the owner or person having the dog in care, possession, or custody, except as may be permitted under exceptions provided in this section. A dog is properly restrained when it is under the control of the owner or person having possession and held by a cord, rope, chain or similar tether. Any such restraint must be applied in a manner to protect the health and safety of the dog. A dog is properly enclosed when it is securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, or physical or electronic fence designed and functioning to prevent the dog from escaping. Dogs classified as dangerous of vicious as defined in O.C.G.A., Title 4, Article 2 shall not be permitted to be confined by electronic fence, and shall be confined in such a manner suitable to prevent entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. 
(b)  Every parent or head of a household where a dog is kept shall be deemed to be a responsible party under and for purposes of this section, even though others might be equally responsible with him with respect to the same dog. The fact that a dog may be owned by a minor child shall be no defense to a parent who is the head of a household. 
(c)  A dog not in a vehicle and securely confined therein, when away from the premises where habitually kept, shall be on a leash and under control of a person capable of controlling the dog and protecting others against harm. 
(d)  Whenever a dog is being transported in a vehicle, it shall not be taken under the vehicle or allowed to escape therefrom at any place other than where habitually kept, unless on a leash and in control of a capable person, as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(e)  Any person leading or allowing their leashed dog onto the property of another is guilty of the crime of trespassing, and can be charged in the municipal court of the city for this crime. 
(f)  It shall be the responsibility of the dog owner or whoever is in charge of the dog at the time to clean up behind their dog. All litter and feces shall be removed from any public or private property immediately, and deposited in a waste receptacle. Failure to clean up behind the animal can result in a citation for littering. 
(Ord. of 2-14-2015; Res. of 6-11-2018, § 1) 
Charter reference- Animals running at large, impounding, § 39. 
Sec. 10-34. - Kennels. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section a kennel is defined as follows: 
(1)  Any person who keeps, feeds, boards, supervises, or trains dogs for hire or compensation; or 
(2)  Any person who owns or is the custodian of more than ten dogs while in a residential district as shown on the official zoning map. 
(b)  Any person(s) fostering animals must have the state required forms and licenses including: a contract with the person(s) for whom they are fostering, the required animal inventory form including the rabies inoculation tag number of each animal being fostered, inspection forms documenting that periodic inspections for cleanliness and sanitation are being done. These forms and licenses must be made available to the animal control officer or the county sheriff's deputy upon request. 
(c)  Failure to provide fostering documentation will result in the location being classified as a kennel, and being subject to the zoning ordinance in regards to operating a business in a residential area. 
(d)  Licensed veterinarians shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
The animal control officer and the county sheriff's department shall be authorized to enforce this section. 
(Res. of 6-11-2018, § 1) 
Sec. 10-35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- A resolution adopted June 11, 2018, repealed § 10-35. Former § 10-35 pertained to breeding and derived from an ordinance adopted February 14, 2015. 
Secs. 10-36-10-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RABIES CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 38. 

Sec. 10-61. - Inoculation tag. 
(a)  Duty of veterinarian. A veterinarian inoculating a dog for rabies shall give to the owner or custodian of the dog a tag showing that such dog has been inoculated, and the owner or custodian of the dog shall attach such tag to a collar or harness on the dog. 
(b)  Failure to have tag. Any dog will be presumed not to have been inoculated if it is not wearing a collar or harness with the inoculation tag attached thereto. 
(c)  Unauthorized tag. It shall be unlawful for any person to tag a dog as evidence of inoculation when the dog in fact has not been inoculated. 
(Code 1989, § 4-22; Ord. of 2-14-2015) 
Sec. 10-62. - Impounding-Authorized/required. 
(a)  Authorized. The animal control officer and/or law enforcement officer shall be authorized to and it shall be the duty of those officers to impound every dog in the city that has not been inoculated pursuant to state law and that does not carry the tag as required in section 10-61. 
(b)  Redemption, disposal. All dogs impounded as provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be kept in the pound for three days, unless diseased or severely injured, during which time such dog may be claimed by its owner or custodian. If claimed and payment is made by the owner of the cost of inoculation and the cost of keeping the dog, the dog shall be returned to such owner or custodian. If the dog is not claimed and the charges are not paid, after being impounded for three days the dog may be destroyed. 
(Code 1989, § 4-23; Ord. of 2-14-2015; Res. of 6-11-2018, § 1) 
Sec. 10-63. - Same-Right of redemption. 
    The owner of any dog caught and impounded as provided in section 10-62 shall be entitled to the possession of the dog upon proof of ownership and presentation or purchase of the inoculation tag provided for in section 10-61. 
(Code 1989, § 4-24; Ord. of 2-14-2015) 
Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:
