(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-121) 
Secs. 90-713-90-740. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MOBILE HOMES/MANUFACTURED HOMES ON INDIVIDUAL LOTS 

Sec. 90-741. - Applicability of division. 
    The requirements and conditions of this division shall apply to the use and placement of mobile homes/manufactured homes on individual lots. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-128) 
Sec. 90-742. - Permitted uses. 
    Mobile homes/manufactured homes on individual lots may be permitted in the city, provided the site and placement of the mobile home/manufactured home conforms to the requirements for residences in the zone in which it is located and permitted. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-129) 
Sec. 90-743. - Minimum requirements. 
    Mobile homes/manufactured homes on individual lots shall be provided with the following improvements to the site, lot and structure itself: 
(1)  Individual connection to the city's water, sewer and electrical systems is required. 
(2)  Wheels, axles, and any towing apparatus shall be removed from the structure. These items must be removed from the premises. 
(3)  All mobile homes/manufactured homes must meet the requirements of the Uniform Standards Code for Manufactured Homes Act (O.C.G.A. § 8-2-130 et seq.). 
(4)  All mobile homes/manufactured homes must meet the rules and regulations for manufactured housing, as prescribed by the state safety and fire commissioner (O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-131(1) and 8-2-132(c). 
(5)  Any mobile home/manufactured home must be so oriented on the lot that its longest axis faces the street. If the planning commission deems it appropriate it may permit deviation from this subsection upon petition. 
(6)  Any mobile home/manufactured home moved into the city limits must pass an inspection by the building official or his designee. A copy of the inspection form, with the inspector's contact information, and license number must be provided before a permit will be issued to set up the mobile home/manufactured home in the city. This inspection will check the condition of the interior and exterior of the home, and all mechanical electrical and plumbing systems to ensure they meet the IRC minimum standard for residences. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-130; Mo. of 8-11-03; Ord. of 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 90-744. - Location restricted. 
    No mobile home/manufactured home shall be located on any lot, parcel, or tract occupied by any other dwelling or mobile home/manufactured home. Only one mobile home/manufactured home shall be located on each individual lot, parcel, or tract except in an approved mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-131) 
Sec. 90-745. - Temporary occupancy. 
(a)  A mobile home/manufactured home or travel trailer may be placed on a lot occupied by a permanent building where it is necessary to provide for the care of a sick or infirm person resident on that lot. A special permit authorizing temporary occupancy shall be required. Such temporary permit shall be issued for a period of one year. 
(b)  Temporary occupancy permits shall be reviewed annually by the mayor and council and renewed only upon detailed review and approval of the circumstances warranting such a renewal. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-132) 
Secs. 90-746-90-770. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MOBILE OFFICES 

Sec. 90-771. - Applicability of division. 
    This division shall apply to the use and placement of mobile offices. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-133) 
Sec. 90-772. - Permitted uses. 
    Mobile offices may be permitted in the city, provided the site and placement of the mobile office conforms to the requirements for commercial structures in the zone in which located and permitted. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-134) 
Sec. 90-773. - Minimum requirements. 
    Mobile offices shall be provided with the following improvements to the site and lot: 
(1)  Individual connection to the city's water, sewer, and electrical systems. 
(2)  A permanent concrete block or brick foundation properly closed and vented supporting the mobile office. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-135) 
DIVISION 6. - SOLAR COLLECTION SYSTEMS 

Sec. 90-774. - In general; all solar systems. 
(a)  Definitions: 
    Solar collection system means a solar energy system that transforms solar energy into another form of energy or transfers heat from a collector to another medium using mechanical, electrical, or chemical means. 
    Small scale solar collection system means a solar collection system that transforms solar energy into another form of energy or transfers heat from a collector to another medium using mechanical, electrical, or chemical means, principally for use on the same property. 
    Solar farm means a solar collection system placed in an area for the purpose of generating photovoltaic electric power principally for use off-site, or where the solar collection system is the primary land use on the parcel where it is located, or where the total area of a ground based or free standing solar collection system occupies more than one acre. This is also referred to as a "solar park," "solar power plant" or "solar photovoltaic farm." 
(b)  Solar collectors shall not emit unreasonable glare. Exterior surfaces of the collectors and related equipment shall have a non-reflective finish. Solar panels shall be placed and arranged such that reflected solar radiation or glare shall not be directed onto the habitable portion of adjacent buildings or properties, or onto roadways, in such manner as to cause a nuisance, impair the vision of a driver of any vehicle, or be detrimental to public health, safety, and welfare. 
(c)  Requirements for labeling and signage, installation, structural certification, roof covering must comply with applicable building codes. 
(d)  All systems must be clearly marked, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Main service disconnect; 
(2)  All conduit, raceways, enclosures, cable assemblies and junction boxes to alert the fire service to avoid cutting them, every ten feet, at turns and at penetrations, and at all combiner and junction boxes. 
(e)  To ensure emergency personnel access, in particular for fire departments, roof mounted systems shall provide access and spacing requirements in order to: 
(1)  Ensure roof access and egress. 
(2)  Provide pathways throughout the roof area. 
(3)  Provide smoke ventilation opportunity areas. 
(f)  No permit shall be issued without proof that any electrical utility with power to the property has been informed of applicant's intent to install a solar collection system. 
(g)  Solar installations in any historic district shall require a certificate of appropriateness pursuant to the city historic preservation ordinance. 
(h)  Solar easements-Property owners installing any solar energy collection system shall be responsible for negotiating with surrounding property owners any desired solar easement, and for properly recording and enforcing same. 
(i)  A ten foot area clear of trees, bushes or brash is required surrounding all ground mounted photovoltaic arrays. Vegetation in the area must be kept trimmed to less than 18 inches. 
(j)  Must be installed according to adopted version of the National Electric Code. 
(Ord. of 12-12-2016) 
Sec. 90-775. - Small scale solar collection systems. 
    Small scale solar collection systems shall be considered an accessory use in all zoning districts in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Freestanding solar panels: 
a.  Shall only be permitted as an accessory use on the lot of a principal structure. 
b.  Shall only be permitted in the rear and side yard the lot of a principal structure, or on the roof of conforming structures. 
c.  When located on the ground or attached to a framework located on the ground shall not exceed 20 feet in height above the ground, or the height of existing structure, whichever is lower. 
d.  Shall conform to all set back requirements as for other uses in the districts in which they are located. 
e.  The total coverage of a lot with freestanding solar panels cannot exceed 50 percent lot coverage or the maximum allowable coverage for the district in which they are located, whichever is less. 
f.  Small solar panel systems not connected to the electrical system of the structures on the property or to the electrical grid in any way, such as solar security or decorative yard lights, and where the solar panel area measures less than two square feet, are exempt from permitting. 
(2)  Roof-mounted solar panels: 
a.  Shall not project vertically more than the height requirements for the district in which they are located. 
b.  Shall only be permitted on the roof of conforming structures so long as such solar collections systems face away from any street immediately adjacent to said conforming structure. 
c.  Where visible from the ground, shall be color-coordinated to harmonize with roof materials and other dominant colors of the structure. 
d.  Owner shall provide proof of notification to the managing authority of any airport located within five miles of the proposed location where the size of the installation exceeds one acre. 
(Ord. of 12-12-2016) 
Sec. 90-776. - Solar farms. 
    Solar farms shall be permitted only in an M-2 general industrial district, in accordance with the following regulations: 
(1)  Solar farms shall be enclosed by perimeter fencing to restrict unauthorized access at a minimum height of six feet, which shall be maintained in good condition, and any gates shall be securely locked. 
(2)  The manufacturers' or installers' identification and appropriate warning signage shall be posted at the site in a clearly visible manner. At least one sign shall be posted at the entrance to the facility showing the owner's name, address and emergency contact information. 
(3)  On-site power lines shall, to the maximum extent practicable, be placed underground. 
(4)  Solar farms shall adhere to the requirements of the district in which they are located, including but not limited to setbacks, height, lot area coverage requirements and buffer requirements. 
a.  Where a solar farm is located on a major street, solar plant structures must be located a minimum of 100 feet from the right-of-way. 
b.  A solar farm with solar panels within 100 feet of any street must have sufficient barriers to prevent a passenger vehicle leaving that street at the maximum speed limit from entering the solar field. A "passenger vehicle" means every motor vehicle having a gross vehicle weight of 10,000 pounds or less. 
(5)  The following requirements shall be met for permit applications: 
a.  A descriptive plot plan including setbacks, panel sizes, locations of property lines, buildings, and road right-of-ways. 
b.  The plan shall include a fire suppression system sufficient to prevent a fire from spreading off the site. 
c.  No solar farm shall be installed until evidence has been given to the city that the electric utility company has been informed of the customer's intent to install an interconnected customer-owned generator. Off-grid systems shall be exempt from this requirement. 
d.  An affidavit or evidence of agreement between lot owner and the facility's owner or operator confirming that the owner or operator has permission of the property owner to apply for necessary permits for construction and operation of the urban solar farm. 
e.  Proof of notification to the managing authority of any airport located within five miles of the proposed location. 
f.  Any other relevant studies, reports, certificates and approvals as may be reasonably requested by the city, including but not limited to design review. 
(6)  The following requirements shall be met for decommissioning solar farms: 
a.  Each applicant for a permit must submit decommissioning plans that describe the anticipated life of the solar project, the party responsible for decommissioning, the estimated decommissioning costs in current dollars, and the method for ensuring by bond that funds will be available for decommissioning and restoration. 
b.  Preferred bond instruments shall include cash or surety from a bonding company with authority to operate in the State of Georgia and approved by the city. The bond shall consist of three components for purposes of determining its amount. The first component will address environmental liabilities including hazardous materials liabilities, such as risks associated with hazardous waste and hazardous substances. The second component will address the decommissioning, removal, and proper disposal, as appropriate, of improvements and facilities. The third component will address reclamation, re-vegetation, restoration, and soil stabilization. There shall be a single instrument to cover all potential liabilities. The entire bond amount may be used to address a single risk event such as hazardous materials release or groundwater contamination regardless of the fact that in calculating the total bond amount other risks were also considered. If the bond is used to address a particular risk, the holder would then be required to increase the bond amount to compensate for this use. 
c.  Solar farms which have not been in active and continuous service for a period of one year shall be removed at the owner's or operator's expense. 
d.  The site shall be restored to as natural condition as possible within six months of the removal. 
e.  A site will be considered decommissioned when, after inspection and approval by the city, all structures and equipment are removed and the site is re-vegetated. 
(Ord. of 12-12-2016) 
Secs. 90-777-90-800. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-801. - Application of chapter. 
    Except as otherwise provided, no structure or land shall, after June 2, 1997, be used and no structure or part thereof shall be erected, altered or moved unless in conformity with the regulations specified in this chapter for the district in which it is located. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be considered minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity, and general welfare of the community. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-140) 
Sec. 90-802. - Enforcing officer. 
    This chapter shall be administered and enforced by the building official. This official shall have the right to enter upon any premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making inspections of buildings or premises necessary to carry out his duties in the enforcement of this chapter. In addition, he shall issue all building permits and make and maintain records thereof, issue all certificates of occupancy and make and maintain records thereof, and conduct inspections as prescribed by this chapter and other such inspections as are necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-141) 
Sec. 90-803. - Building permits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commence the excavation for the construction of any building or structure, including accessory structures, or to commence the moving, alteration, or repair of any structure, including accessory structures, until the building official has issued for such work a building permit containing a statement that the plans, specifications and intended use of such structure in all respects conform with this chapter. 
(b)  Application for a building permit shall be made in writing to the building official on forms provided for that purpose. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the building official to approve the plans or issue a building permit for any excavation or construction until he has inspected such plans in detail and found them to be in conformity with this chapter. To this end, the building official shall require that every application for a building permit for excavation, construction, moving, or alteration shall be accompanied by a plan or plat drawn to scale and showing the following in sufficient detail to enable the building official to ascertain whether the proposed excavation, construction, moving or alteration is in conformance with this chapter: 
(1)  The actual shape, location, and dimensions of the lot to be built upon. 
(2)  The shape, height, use and location on the lot of buildings or structures to be erected or altered. 
(3)  The sizes, locations, and use of all existing buildings or structures on the lot. 
(4)  The number of dwelling units the building, if residential, is designed to accommodate. 
(5)  The setback lines of buildings on adjoining lots. 
(6)  The layout of off-street parking and unloading spaces. 
(7)  The signature of the county health officer approving the proposed location of the septic tank, and field lines provided public sewerage is not available. 
(8)  Such other information concerning the lot or adjoining lots as may be essential for determining whether this chapter is being observed. 
(d)  If the proposed excavation, construction, moving or alteration as set forth in the application for a building permit is in conformity with this chapter, the building official shall issue a building permit for such excavation, construction, moving or alteration. 
(e)  If the application for a building permit is not approved, the building official shall state in writing on the application the cause for such disapproval. Issuance of a permit shall, in no case, be construed as waiving any section of this chapter, and building permits shall be void after six months from the date of issuance unless substantial progress on the project has been made by that time. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-142) 
Sec. 90-804. - Use permit. 
    The building official shall not issue a building permit for a conditional use until such conditional use is approved by the planning commission and a conditional use permit issued therefor. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-143) 
Sec. 90-805. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    No land or building or other structure or part thereof erected, moved, or altered in its use shall be occupied or used until the building official has issued a certificate of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy shall be issued only if the building or premises is found to conform to this chapter. If the certificate of occupancy is not granted upon request, the building official shall state in writing the reasons the certificate was not granted. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-144) 
Sec. 90-806. - Procedure for zoning change. 
    The procedures in this section shall be required when any person other than the mayor and council or planning commission requests a change in the zoning district boundaries. The mayor and council may from time to time amend, supplement, or change by ordinance the boundaries on the zoning districts established on the zoning map of the city or the regulations set forth in this chapter. Any proposed amendment, supplement, or change shall first be submitted to the planning commission for its recommendation. Before the mayor and council takes action resulting in a zoning decision, a public hearing shall be conducted. The procedures for advertising and holding the public hearing shall be as follows: 
(1)  Any person desiring a zoning change in the existing boundaries of any zoning district shall first file a petition requesting such change with the city administrator, together with a plat of the property to be changed and the rezoning fee prescribed by the mayor and council from time to time and filed in the office of the city administrator. 
(2)  Within 15 days after receiving the petition, the city clerk shall in writing inform the applicant of the date on which a public hearing will be held by the mayor and council for the zoning change. 
(3)  Upon filing of a petition for a zoning change and receiving notice of the date of the public hearing concerning the petitioned request, the applicant shall at his expense erect or cause to be erected in a conspicuous place on the property in question a sign giving public notice of both the existing zoning district in which the property is located and the requested change, the scheduled date for the public hearing, and the name and address of the property owner. Such sign shall be not less than nine square feet in area with not less than two-inch black letters upon a white background stating the required information. 
(4)  At least 15 days but not more than 45 days prior to the scheduled public hearing, the city clerk shall advertise such hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and shall notify all property owners within 400 feet of the subject property by mail. 
(5)  Prior to the public hearing the planning commission shall prepare an assessment and recommendation on the proposal using the following criteria, and shall advise the mayor and council of its findings: 
a.  Existing uses and zoning of nearby property. 
b.  The extent to which property values are diminished by the particular zoning restrictions. 
c.  The extent to which the destruction of property values of the plaintiff promotes the health, safety, morals, or general welfare of the public. 
d.  The relative gain to the public, as compared to the hardship imposed upon the individual property owner. 
e.  The suitability of the subject property for the zoned purposes. 
f.  The length of time the property has been vacant as zoned considered in the context of land development in the area in the vicinity of the property. 
g.  Conformity with or divergence from the land use plan. 
(6)  Copies of the draft, zoning ordinance and map, plus the evaluation of the proposed district boundary changes, will be made available for public review during normal working hours between the date of the appearance of the public hearing notice and the time of the public hearing. 
(7)  The public hearing shall be conducted by the mayor and council. 
(8)  The mayor and council will review for those present procedures and set forth the operating procedures for the hearing as follows: 
a.  In order for a person in attendance to speak, the chair must recognize the person. Upon rising to speak, the person recognized will first identify himself. The chair may also request that the person furnish a home or business street address, as appropriate. 
b.  The person speaking will be allowed a reasonable time to express opinions and make points on each separate element of the proposed revisions which the person wishes to address, with a maximum total of ten minutes allowed per person. 
c.  Additional persons will be recognized per the procedure in this subsection for the purpose of addressing additional elements of the proposed revision or to make additional points with regard to elements already addressed, but not to rehash points already made. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-155) 
Sec. 90-807. - Violations, penalties and remedies. 
(a)  A violation of any section of this chapter is declared to be a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(b)  If any building or structure is or is proposed to be erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, converted, or maintained or if any building, structure or land is or is proposed to be used in violation of this chapter, the building official, city attorney, or other appropriate authority of the city or any adjacent or neighboring property owner who would be specially damaged by violation may, in addition to other remedies, institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance, or use or to correct or abate such violation or to prevent the occupancy of the building, structure, or land. 
(c)  Each and every day such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance, or use continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-156) 
Sec. 90-808. - Conflict with other laws. 
    Whenever the provisions of any ordinance, resolution or other statute require more restrictive standards than are required by this chapter, the provisions of such other ordinance, resolution, or statute shall govern. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-158) 
Sec. 90-809. - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall take effect from and after the effective date of its passage and publication as required by law. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-159) 
Secs. 90-810-90-835. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 90-836. - Established. 
(a)  A board of zoning appeals is established to hear and decide appeals and to authorize variances in the terms of this chapter. 
(b)  The board of zoning appeals shall consist of at least three members and not more than five members. Members appointed to the board shall hold no other public office except that one may also be a member of the planning commission. The members shall serve for overlapping terms of three years. The chairman shall be elected by the board from its membership. The board shall adopt rules in accordance with this chapter for the conduct of its affairs. Meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board may determine. 
(c)  There shall be an additional three individuals appointed to the board of zoning appeals whose duties shall be to hear and decide appeals and to authorize variances only as allowed in this chapter in all matters pertaining to signs and other outdoor advertising as set forth in chapter 58. In these matters relating to signs and outdoor advertising, this committee shall act as the board of zoning appeals. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-145) 
Sec. 90-837. - Appeals. 
    An appeal to the board of zoning appeals may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any governmental officer, department, board, or bureau affected by any decision of the building official based in whole or in part upon this chapter. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the board of zoning appeals a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The building official shall transmit to the board all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed was taken. The board shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal or other matters referred to it, shall give public notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days before the hearing, and shall decide the appeal within a reasonable period of time. Any person may appear at the hearing in person, by agent, or by attorney. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-146) 
Sec. 90-838. - Powers; appeals from decisions. 
(a)  The board of zoning appeals shall have the power to: 
(1)  Hear and decide appeals where it is alleged by the appellant that there is error in any order, requirement, permit, decision, determination, or refusal made by the building official or other administrative official in carrying out or enforcing any section of this chapter. 
(2)  Hear requests for interpretation of the zoning map, and for the decision of any special questions upon which the board of zoning appeals is authorized to pass. 
(3)  Hear and decide applications for variances from the terms of this chapter. 
(4)  Hear and decide appeals from the approval or disapproval of the planning commission of the application for a conditional use permit. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by any decision of the board of zoning appeals or any taxpayer or any officer, department or board of the city may present to a court of record a petition, duly verified, setting forth that such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, and specifying the grounds of such illegality. Such petition shall be presented to the court within ten days after the filing of the decision complained of in the offices of the board and not thereafter. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-147) 
Sec. 90-839. - Variances. 
(a)  After written denial of a building permit, a property owner may make an application for a variance from this chapter, using the form available. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application and payment of the variance fee, as prescribed from time to time by the mayor and council and filed in the office of the city administrator, with the city administrator, the board of zoning appeals shall hold a public hearing, after having first given public notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city 15 days prior to the date of the hearing, and will notify all property owners within 400 feet of the property in question by mail of the variance request. The board shall consider and decide all applications for variances within 30 days of such public hearing and in accordance with the standards provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Variances from the terms of this chapter may be granted in such individual hardship cases of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the board of zoning appeals based on the following criteria: 
(1)  Variances shall be granted only where special circumstances or conditions fully described in the findings of the board do not apply generally to the district. 
(2)  Variances shall not be granted to allow a use otherwise excluded from the particular district in which requested. 
(3)  For reasons fully set forth in the findings of the board, the special circumstances or conditions are such that the strict application of this chapter would deprive the applicant of any reasonable use of his land. Mere loss in value shall not justify a variance. There must be deprivation of beneficial use of land. 
(4)  The granting of any variance shall be in harmony with the general purposes and intent of this chapter and shall not be injurious to the neighborhood, detrimental to the public welfare, or in conflict with the comprehensive plan for development. 
(5)  In reviewing an application for a variance, the burden of showing that the variance should be granted shall be upon the person applying therefor. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-148) 
Secs. 90-840-90-865. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROCEDURES FOR AUTHORIZING CONDITIONAL USES 

Sec. 90-866. - Application to planning commission. 
(a)  An application requesting a conditional use of land or structure as provided for in the zoning district regulations shall be filed with the planning commission for review. The application shall show the location and intended uses of the site, the name of the property owners and existing land uses within 400 feet, and other material pertinent to the request which the planning commission may require. 
(b)  Every applicant for a conditional use permit shall be charged a fee, as prescribed from time to time by the mayor and council and filed in the office of the city administrator. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-149) 
Sec. 90-867. - Restrictions. 
    In the exercise of its approval of a conditional use, the planning commission may impose such conditions regarding the location, character, or other features of the proposed uses or buildings as it may deem advisable and necessary in the furtherance of the general purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-150) 
Sec. 90-868. - Validity of plans. 
    All approved plans, conditions, restrictions, and rules made part of the approval of the conditional use by the planning commission shall constitute certification on the part of the applicant that the proposed use shall conform to such regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-151) 
Sec. 90-869. - Use permit. 
    Upon approval of all plans, including any restrictions, as provided in this division, the planning commission shall issue a conditional use permit. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-152) 
Sec. 90-870. - Time limit. 
    Every application for a conditional use under this chapter shall be decided within 45 days of the date of application, and the applicant shall be provided with a written notice of either approval or denial. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-153) 
Sec. 90-871. - Public hearing. 
    Prior to taking action on any request for a conditional use permit, the planning commission shall hold a public hearing. The procedures for advertising and holding the public hearing shall be as provided in subsections 90-806(2), (3) and (4), except that the planning commission shall conduct the hearing. 
(Ord. of 6-2-1997, § 19-154) 
Secs. 90-872-90-900. - Reserved.

CODE COMPARATIVE TABLE - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS 
This table gives the location within this Code of those ordinances and resolutions adopted since the 1989 Code, as updated through April 8, 1996, which are included herein. Ordinances and resolutions adopted prior to such date were incorporated into the 1989 Code, as supplemented. This table contains some ordinances and resolutions which precede April 8, 1996, but which were never included in the 1989 Code, as supplemented, for various reasons. Ordinances and resolutions not listed herein have been omitted as repealed, superseded or not of a general and permanent nature.
